Regina, Sask., April 24th 1924.

Dear Mr. Scott,

I have just returned from the Province of Alberta, where I have been for nearly three weeks. I visited the Blood, Peigan, Sarcee, Blackfoot, Hobbema and Edmonton Agencies, and eight Indian Boarding Schools.

BLOOD RESERVE.

I visited the Roman Catholic Blood School, which is situated on this Reserve. There are eleven Sisters in this Institution and between sixty and seventy children. As usual, I found the children in excellent shape - clean, well dressed and tidy. This was not a dress parade. The children are well fed and good work is being done here. This work, however, is being carried on under great disadvantages. The present school building is certainly unfit to carry on work in. However, the time is not far distant I hope, when they will enjoy a new building; and when it is built and operated, it will be a credit to the Indian Department. The work they are now doing under great disadvantages would be discouraging to most people. As it is, I found everything in the old building immaculate. They want to do a little brightening up of the interior of the classroom and livingroom, and asked to be allowed to have a little paint to do this work. I gave the Agent the necessary authority to purchase a small quantity of paint. The vouchers for this will pass through this office.

(Sgd.) W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

D.C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Commissioner's Office,
Regina, Sask. April 17, 1924.

Dear Mr. Stewart:

I am sending to you under separate cover plans for a cow barn and horse barn which I propose building at the new Anglican School on the Blood Reserve, and for the Roman Catholic School on the same Reserve, which school is to be built in a year from now.

I wish particularly to draw your attention to the construction of these buildings. The cattle barn is on the usual concrete foundation with proper footings. The walls have two thicknesses of shiplap with paper, as well as drop siding. It has a concrete floor throughout. The stanchions are of iron as well as the divisions between the stalls; in fact the building throughout is modern construction. The horse barn is built almost in the same way, except that the stalls are plank, the driveway is concrete and the mangers are wooden.

In addition to these two buildings there is a warehouse required at the Agency. This building is to be 48 ft. long and 24 ft. wide, heavy construction.

I have received an offer to build the whole three buildings for $5500. In other words, we are getting the three buildings for one-third what it cost to put up one stable at Edmonton, or one-half what it cost to build one stable at Blackfoot. There is nothing cheap about these buildings. The construction is heavy. I just want you to see the plans before I start doing the work. I would either let a contract; or send a man up to take charge, and buy the material locally. If I let a contract, it would be necessary to have Blue Prints taken. This could be done here, as well as getting out a list of material.

I am sending these plans, so that you can see what we are getting for our money, and I would ask you to kindly return them after you have examined them.

Yours faithfully,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Hon. Chas. Stewart,
Superintendent General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Ottawa, May 12, 1924.

Dear Mr. Graham,

With further reference to your letter to the Minister of April 17th, I beg to say that I discussed this matter with the Minister yesterday. I think he intends to reply to you direct with reference to the barn which you proposed to erect on the site chosen for the Roman Catholic school on the Blood Reserve to the effect that we cannot find funds for it this year.

You may proceed with the erection of the two barns for the new Anglican school. I note from your letter that you have received an offer "to build the whole three buildings for $5,500.00." I presume you meant the three barns. If so, the two barns which you were authorized to erect will cost less than this amount and we will therefore be able to find funds for their construction.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Superintendent General.

W.M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

September 5th 1924.

To D.G. Scott
Deputy Minister of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Honorable Sir:

I have the honor to make application to the Department of Indian Affairs for the construction of a new Roman Catholic Residential School on the Blood Indian Reserve, Province of Alberta.

Many reasons well known to the officials of the Department of Education urge me to make this request which I hope you will be able to grant. These reasons are as follows:

1st. Our actual residential school was condemned sixteen years ago on account of the proximity of the river which in the spring time overflows and floods the buildings making the place unhealthy for the staff and pupils.

2nd. Since the buildings were condemned no repairs of any account were made with the result that they are in a state of delapidation.

3rd. The actual school built originally for fifty pupils is filled to capacity, yet there, on the Reserve many others who cannot be admitted for lack of space and accommodation (there are about 150 children of school age who are members of our Church.)

4th. A new residential school has been erected for the
Church of England and our Indians claim the same privilege for their children.

5th. If this request was refused we would be in danger of losing many pupils who by right belong to us on account of the inferiority of our position.

For these reasons and many others unnecessary to mention here, I beg from the Indian Department to build us a new school without delay. It is urgently needed and I have no doubt that my demand which is also the demand of all the Catholic Indians of the Blood Reserve will be granted and that the work will begin as soon as possible.

I am honorable Sir,

respectfully yours,

[Signature]

E. Ricouer

Sir,

File No. 103-2-15.

Referring to your letter of 21st Ult., I have gone into the matter of what pupilage should be arranged for in the proposed new Blood R. C. School with Father Ruaux.

After going through my Treaty books & taking into consideration the improved living conditions & the better prospects for raising the children born on the Reserve, I have come to the conclusion that the school should be built to accommodate not less than 160 children & 24 members of the staff.

A school such as this is not being built for today but for the years to come & it will be much better to anticipate the requirements than to build for the present & find that after five years or so the building will have to be added to.

Your obedient Servant,

Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
while other Reserves were decreasing by half. For the last three years, there is even a manifest increase. They have given themselves to farming and success has crowned their efforts. They have more money, comfortable houses and instead of living in camps each one has his own farm. Morality has benefited by this change. Scrofula has almost entirely disappeared, the children are healthy and full of life. The Reverend Father has in the Reserve 70 catholic families. Let us suppose that each family has only two children between seven and eighteen, this would bring that number to 140; some families have even more. The Reverend Father has christianed to date 37 children, which shows that the birth rate is on the increase and therefore the future must be taken into account in the construction of the school. It is therefore the idea of the Reverend Father that the Department should build for about 175 children. If this number cannot be accommodated immediately there is a certainty that before long this number will be reached.

Hoping that you will give your kind consideration to the accompanying letter and the above remarks, I remain

Yours very truly,

Joseph [signature]

December 11, 1924

Dear Mr. Ferrier:

At your request I have written to Reverend Father E. Rusaux, Principal of the Blood Indian Residential School, in connection with the number of children, the new R.C. Residential School should be built for. Please find hereafter copy of the Principal's letter.

"Reverend Father,

As directed by Mr. D. C. Scott, Mr. Faunt Indian Agent, met me yesterday to discuss the number of children, the new R.C. Residential School should be built for.

After submitting to him the number of catholic families on the Reserve with their children, and the list of pagan Indians whose children we have already, we easily agreed that the Department should not build for less than 160 children and the following Staff.

One Principal.
Sixteen Sisters.
One farmer instructor.
Two male teachers.
Two handy men (attendants).
One engineer.
One skilled artisan (carpenter and blacksmith).

I am, Reverend Father,
Sincerely yours
(Sgd) E. Rusaux, O.M.I."

To justify the request of the Reverend Principal, I must state the following. The population on the Reserve number 1160 and in spite of the changes in the mode of living of our Indians, which from Buffalo hunters made them farmers, they have always maintained their number;

Memorandum:

1. Dr. Scott
2. Mr. Orr.

The Department has corresponded with the church officials and with the Indian agent, with reference to the accommodation which should be provided in the proposed new Blood R.C. Indian Residential School building. I have made a study of the census of some years ago and that of last year and I have discussed the question with Mr. Commissioner Graham. I am convinced that we should provide for a maximum pupilage of 160 children. The church authorities have intimated that there will be on the staff of this institution when completed a principal, seven other male officers or labourers and sixteen Sisters.

Supt. of Indian Education.
February 14, 1925.

Memorandum,

Hon. Charles Stewart.

Stand-Off, Alberta.
February 7th 1925.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

With reference to the plans of the Duck Lake, Sask. Residential School, which were sent here some time ago to Rev. Fr. Ruaux, Principal of the above School, for his consideration and suggestions, I beg to inform you that these plans are being returned to you under separate cover.

Having been at Duck Lake not only while the plans were being prepared, but also at different times during the construction of the building, I thought I was in a position to discuss this matter here with Rev. Fr. Ruaux. Consequently I have drawn sketches of the different floors according to the same size building as at Duck Lake; these sketches are not exact as to scale, but might prove sufficient to convey to you the trend of our suggestions and help you to draw up the new ones. These are included among the returned plans.

The main change is the location of the accommodation for the boys to the wing intended for the girls, and vice versa. Now, Dear Sir, allow me to submit the following detailed suggestions which I have gathered particularly after my last visit to Duck Lake a month ago, when the new building was about completed, and thus I was acquainted with some changes made.

BASEMENT.

Recreation-room walls should be plastered, instead of being left with rough brick; a coat of cement up to five feet high. Wash-rooms; walls to be painted. Washing-throughs: in boys and girls rooms, having taps on both sides, are not wide enough for convenient washing; should be 26 inches wide instead of 18 inches. Washing-through: on floor for boys fast, is not deep enough; though standard size, could be made deeper to order at the factory, viz., 8 inches deep, and thus avoid spilling. Dining-room & Recreation-room Floors should be painted with two coats of regular cement floor paint, in order to keep same clean; if not painted, stains cannot be removed from from the rough cement floor. This should apply also to the floors in the washrooms and more particularly to the floors of Toilets in both Recreation rooms. Toilets in girls Recreation-room to be reduced a little in size. Toilets (closets) for girls should all have doors. Windows in Washrooms and Toilets should have non-transparent panes of glass. Wire-Screens, heavy, for inside windows in Boys Recreation-room. Doors, to Washrooms, Lavatories, Boiler-room, Engine-room, Bakery, Dairy, Stores, and Laundry need not be of the same finished model, with panels and mouldings, as in the other rooms; Doors, strong, to be put, as marked, in both Recreation-rooms, opening to passage leading to Dining-room. (On the Duck Lake plan these were left open; which is most unpleasant).
Coat-room (Boys): Have placed therein a toilet and a basin for use only of the workingmen, such as farmer, engineer, laborers, and other male-help, so as to keep the Toilet-room on the Ground Floor in a cleaner condition for the other staff and Visitors.

Radiators in Basement, more particularly in the Dining-room, Recreation-rooms, Kitchen, etc., might, to advantage, be placed higher up to the ceiling.

Kitchen: floor to be covered with Battleship (cork) linoleum.

Laundry: Rainwater from the roofs to be collected into an outside Cistern, whence to be pumped into a storage steel-tank in the Laundry, which raised high enough will supply this soft water to the Laundry tubs.

Manhole: small size, to be placed in line with the other machinery. All this Laundry Machinery to be supplied with steam from a small upright steam-boiler.

Stove: for heating flat-irons (for ironing linen).

Ventilator: large size, in wall behind Laundry Machinery.

Location changed for Dairy, Bakery & Stores; the largest room being for Bakery.

Porches: to both Recreation rooms, to be somewhat larger or more extended, as they are to be the main exit for the pupils to the play-grounds; and there should be a strong door at the bottom, on the floor of the Recreation-room.

Coal-Bin: large enough to hold two cars of coal.

Wall: already dug, would be placed conveniently in corner of Boiler-room, as marked, and with pump and gasoline engine.

GROUND FLOOR:

Corridors: These are rather dark, as there are no transoms over the doors to let in some light; transoms would also afford some ventilation into the individual rooms. If transoms are not to be put in, I would suggest that the upper pannel of the different rooms, except the toilet-rooms and stores, be a non-transparent glass.

Painting: I would suggest that the walls in the corridors and also along the stairs be painted 4 ft. high, as the white plastered walls are liable to be stained or soiled soon and cannot be washed or cleaned.

Floors: tar-paper between the shiplap floor and the hard-wood.

Toilets: on this floor, as well as on all the other floors, should not be set on a wooden floor; there is bound to be some spilling of water; the floor will gradually become saturated and cannot be washed out; disagreeable and harmful odors will be the consequence. Would suggest some kind of a finished, polished cement floor, and this more particularly in both Dormitories for the pupils.

Bath-tubs: on this floor and on the 1st Floor should be 6ft or at least 5ft², for the staff, instead of 5ft.

Pharmacy: No bath-tub required; only the wash-basin and sink.

Stairway: private, for staff to Dining-room, to have an electric light, both way.

Telephone: One in the office of the Principal, and the other in the Matron's office.
CHAPEL.

Back part, as shown raised with one step the whole width of the Chapel. Platform for the altar should have two steps; to of upper platform to be 10ft wide and 7ft deep.

With regard to the Chapel, may I suggest a flat roof instead of a pitched, shingle roof; it would be more in uniformity with the style of the whole building and would give it a better appearance. Several people have made the remark to that effect. I presume that the cost would not be any greater. In that case, the walls would have to be higher, allowing fifteen feet inside, and thus give a standing capacity in the Balcony of about seven feet, and thereby afford more seating capacity for choir. Also in that case the windows should be somewhat larger in height. The metallic ceiling, if not plastered, might be drawn up in large panels.

If the span of the roof over the Chapel, in that case, would require steel posts, four of these could be placed in such a way as to allow a passage of five feet wide in the centre of the Chapel.

FIRST FLOOR.

On this floor, you will notice that it is desired to have the disposition of the two wings reversed from the Boys to the Girls. Also the Balconies have been added.

SECOND FLOOR.

The room for staff in the Centre Dormitories may be reduced in size. Another room for staff has been added in each of the Dormitories in the wings. These are absolutely needed as we are very particular about the supervision in all Dormitories.

In the large Dormitories (wings), the slop-sinks are to be placed close to the steel posts, and lumber wash-stands to be built as marked; the same is being done at the Dusk Lake School.

I would suggest that building paper be placed on the ceiling between the shiplap and the metallic ceiling in all the Dormitories, for saving the heat in winter.

Would you specify that all iron or steel posts be finished off smoothly; I remarked that the ones at Dusk Lake came from the Factory in a very rough state, and unfit for painting.

Do you not think that it would be more economical to have the platform and steps in front of the main Entrance, built in cement and brick posts, instead of with lumber; it would last longer and look a great deal better.

EXCAVATION. I would suggest that the excavation be not made too deep, at least around the main building, so that not only the entire windows appear well above the ground, but that the excavated earth be used to bank up around the building, make it appear higher and thus, with a slope, water will easily run away from the foundations.
The white line of stone trimming on top of the building at Duck Lake, was increased by two inches in width, and I believe four inches would be better still.

Would you not approve of another white stone line between the Ground Floor and First Floor? And on top of the walls on the wings would you not also approve of a little design similar to the one in the centre, but smaller, and thereby improve the appearance.

I would also call your attention to a CORNER STONE or suitable plate with inscription:

IMMACULATE CONCEPTION RES.SCHOOL. - 1925.

Furniture: With regards to furniture, such as wash-stands, cupboards, tables, benches, clothes-closets, shelves, etc., etc., may I ask you to use the sketches that were sent to your office by Mr. Taillon, Inspector of works at Duck Lake.

You will notice that we have figured out the plans for accommodating 175 children; there is not the slightest doubt that in the near future we will have no difficulty in securing that number according to all calculations, and the dispositions of our Indian population on the Blood Reserve, and we feel sure that the Department will approve of this.

I hope, Dear Sir, that I have not presumed too much in making all the above suggestions; I have acted with the idea of improving the usefulness of the building as well as aiding the interests of the Department, and with no idea whatever of extravagance. I trust therefore that you will deign to take the suggestions into consideration, and if I dare to express a preference, it would be with regards to the roof and the size of the Chapel.

I remain, Sir,

Yours respectfully,

A. Naevius, a.m.l.
Procurator for
The Oblate Fathers.

P.S. I understand that you have all the informations with regards to the line for sewerage, and the location for the septic tank.

Dear Sir,

Since writing to you the other day concerning the plans for the new school for the above institution here, I had occasion to visit the St Paul's new school nearby, and I take the liberty of writing you again on this matter.

I noticed in the St Paul's school that the upper panel of the doors in the corridors had been replaced by Murrine Glass, which I have also suggested as an improvement on the Duck Lake plan; also that the walls in the corridors and stairways had been covered, 4 feet high, with Bur'ap, which is better than paint on the walls.

In the sketches submitted, I had placed the well in the corner of the Boiler-room. I believe now it would be better in the corner of the Lighting-room; if this room is too small, it could be made larger by removing the wall of the Laundry.- May we ask you for the same kind of pump as is installed at St Paul's School, which is giving great satisfaction.

As a consequence of changing the place of the well, the small upright steam-boiler could then be placed in the corner of the Boiler-room, which we had marked out for the well.

I have been informed that the water in the well dug for the new school, contains a great deal of soda. Therefore I do hope that you will provide for the outside cement rain-water Cistern, the same as at Duck Lake, for the sake of the Boilers, Laundry, etc.- At Duck Lake, a steam-pipe has been run into this outside cistern, in case of frost.

I beg to remain, Dear Sir,

Yours sincerely,

A. Haessens, O.M.I.
Procurator.

**STARTING.** No heating lamp whatever is required for starting, or during the running of either the Oil or the Petrol Engine. The Oil Engine is started from cold by using a small quantity of petrol or benzoline, after which the fuel supply is changed over to paraffin, petroleum, or kerosene, etc.

DESIGN. The Engine is of the most recent construction, with all our latest improvements introduced to internal-combustion Engines of this class. The general design gives great strength and rigidity, good general appearance, and extreme simplicity of working parts.

ENGINE FRAME. The Engine Frame is strong, and well adapted for hard work, and an oil groove is formed all round the lower portion. It is dust-proof, and is fitted with inspection doors, to enable the working parts to be easily examined.

CYLINDER. The Cylinder Jacket, Liner, Combustion Chamber, and Exhaust Valve Box are cast in one piece, avoiding troublesome face joints and leaky water passages. The construction of the cylinder and the arrangement of the valves are such as to obtain the highest efficiency and economy, and to render them easily accessible. Ample space is provided for the free circulation of the cooling water around the walls and valve seats most exposed to the temperature of the explosions. The open end of the cylinder is carefully fitted into the bed and held in position by powerful bolts.

MAGNETO-ELECTRIC IGNITION. The ignition of the charges is effected by a High-Tension Magneto-Electric apparatus, with Variable Timing Device.

A very desirable feature in any Magneto-Electric Ignition Gear is a means for altering the position of the ignition point in the crank path while the Engine is running; such an arrangement is really requisite, as it enables the Engine to be started satisfactorily at starting, at "light" as well as at other loads, with a resultant economy in fuel consumption. In the case of many Engines on the market, the ignition gear supplied is not capable of being altered while the Engine is running.

FUEL SUPPLY TANK. A galvanized-iron tank of ample capacity is provided for the fuel supply, with connections to the inlet valve on the Engine, and a small vessel for holding a supply of petrol to enable Engine to be started from cold.

GOVERNOR. With the "Throttle" system of governing, a Spring-loaded Revolving Governor is provided, by means of which the fuel inlet valve is throttled so as to control the amount of the charge, with the result that there is a less impulse in the cylinder with the lighter loads than with the heavier ones.

The Governor is specially sensitive, and gives the fullest economy and steadiness under all conditions of working; the Engine only consuming fuel in proportion to the work being done, thereby avoiding waste.

CRANKSHAFT. The Crankshaft is of selected mild steel, and runs in long adjustable white-metal bearings, with "ring" oilers.

CONNECTING ROD. The Connecting Rod is of stamped mild steel, and has adjustable bearings at the large end.
General Specification—(continued)

CAM-SHAFT. The Cam-shaft is of steel, fitted with machined cams, and driven by machine-cut gear wheels.

FLYWHEELS. The Engine is fitted with two Flywheels, machined on face and edges; a turned cast-iron driving pulley is also supplied with the Engines for General Purposes.

LUBRICATION. The main bearings are provided with continuous "ring" oilers, running in an oil bath. The connecting rod, piston and cylinder liner are lubricated by "splash" lubrication, which maintains a surplus of oil over all the working parts, so that they are thoroughly and efficiently lubricated. This system of lubrication considerably reduces wear and tear, and requires less attention than sight-fed oil cups.

ACCESSORIES. With each Engine is provided:
- A cast-iron exhaust chamber.
- Main oil-supply tank.
- Cleaning tools.
- A set of spanners.
- Foundation plan, with full instructions as to fixing and working.

SPARES. The following Spare Parts are also provided:
- One piston ring.
- One spring of each size used on the Engine.

TESTING. Each Engine is carefully tested before leaving the Works, both at "no load" and at the power specified in the Catalogue, to ensure satisfactory working and correct adjustment of all the parts. Any purchaser desiring to satisfy himself as to the power of his Engine must notify beforehand his intention of being present (or of sending someone on his behalf to be present) at this test; or a certificate of test may be had on application.

MATERIALS AND WORKMANSHIP. All materials used in the manufacture of our Oil Engines are of best quality only, and first-class workmanship is employed in their construction, erection and testing.

PAINTING. The Engine is carefully painted in a first-class manner with enamel paint.

GUARANTEE. In lieu of any warranty implied by law, TANGYES LIMITED expressly undertake to repair or supply new any part of the Engine which, in consequence of either faulty material or workmanship, may break show undue wear, or prove to be defective, within a period of twelve months (i.e., one year of ordinary working days of ten to twelve hours) from the date of invoice of the Engine, provided that such failure be not due to improper usage or neglect; that Tangye's Gas Engine Oil (which is specially prepared for use in their Engines) is only used for the lubrication of the cylinder; and that, if required, the defective part is forwarded without delay to TANGYES LIMITED, BIRMINGHAM, for examination. But the installation is supplied by TANGYES LIMITED on the distinct understanding that they shall not be held liable for losses of any kind or for consequential damages arising from stoppages that may be caused by such defect.

Dear Sir:— Re Roman Catholic Blood School

Enclosed is confirmation of night letter sent you yesterday with reference to tender on Blood School. We trust this telegram reached you without delay. We regret that a mistake had been made, it being addressed to Victor G. Scott. This was not noticed until this morning.

Up to time of writing we have had no reply to said night letter, and while we feel sure that you will approve of our suggestion, yet to avoid any exception that might be taken by any parties to our bid being made without the regular deposit, we are attaching our cheque for $9500.00, which, added to the $4,000.00 submitted with Sturgeon Landing bid, will make a total deposit for the Blood School of $13,500.00.

We acknowledge receipt of your telegram of the 14th advising us that you are transferring our deposit cheque on Sturgeon Landing to apply on Blood School.

With Progress Certificate No.8 for $4,462.90 and No.9 for $9,373.50 still outstanding on the Kamloops school, we have outstanding to our credit and unpaid the sum of $13,856.40. On account of making full deposit on the Blood school, as provided for in conditions of tender, we cannot arrange to be without payment on Kamloops for any length of time, and if we are awarded—as we hope we may be—the Blood school contract, will you kindly allow us to make it a condition that either payment on Kamloops is promptly made us, or that the tender deposit on the Blood school be returned to us, and the funds due us and unpaid on Kamloops, (or sufficient of them to make a ten percent deposit on our bid) be held as our final deposit.

By the above we mean that while we have met formal demand for contract deposit, we submit that the Department, having an equal amount to our credit under a contract unpaid, will be prepared to let this credit be our deposit. We trust this will meet with your approval.

If any message from you in reply to our nightletter or the 14th reaches us before Monday next, we will try to have it answered by wire to you before tenders are opened. We are taking most exceptional precautions and care to try and secure this work, and it is possible we may receive some news which may move us to revise our bid. If this is the case will you kindly accept any telegraph figures from us which reach you before the opening of tenders, to take the place of the figures named on the form of tender.

Memorandum:

Honourable Charles Stewart,

I beg to submit herewith the tenders received for the erection of the Roman Catholic School on the Blood Reserve.

We had estimated this building to cost about $130,000.00, and I am constrained not to recommend the lowest tender, which is not in the proper form. This school cannot possibly be erected according to specifications for $111,000.00, and I consider it not in the interests of the Department to accept this tender. The next highest tender, namely, $117,277.00 is entirely regular, and is offered by a firm that in the past has done very excellent work under contract for this Department. I think it, therefore, in the best interests of the project to recommend the acceptance of the Smith Bros. and Wilson tender.

Deputy Superintendent General.

Reverend Sir:

I have had a letter from the man who owns a section of land seven miles Southwest of Claresholm, and he is prepared to make a very good deal if he can sell this winter. As stated in my previous letter he owns 640 acres of land nearly all of which is tillable. There are 560 acres broken. There is a running stream on the land which could be used for irrigation. He has a good five roomed house, and a barn sixty feet long, which has stabling accommodation for 22 horses, together with loft which holds 60 tons of hay. In addition he has a cattle shed 200 ft long, chicken house, granary and some other small buildings.

Over 500 acres of this place are fenced with woven wire, which is very expensive if bought now, and which makes the very best kind of fence, far better than barbed
Mostly all the improvements on this place would be suitable for the purpose which Mr. Graham has in view. He has also 50 tons of hay, 15 head of horses, 6 head of cattle, binder, seeder, plows, harrows, two mowers, rake, soil packer, hay stacker, two hay sweeps, and in fact everything needed for the proper cultivation of the place. My opinion is that if he were sure of an all cash deal, that he would sell everything he has got on the place, as above mentioned for $60.00 per acre.

Perhaps you would be good enough to convey this information to Mr. Graham, and in the meantime I intend running out and making examination of the place next Monday, and will report to you on my return the exact details as I find them.

Memorandum:

Honourable Sir James Lougheed,

With reference to the inclosed letter from Mr. H.A. MacKie, M.P., asking for information for Rev. Father Nassens, Principal of the High River school, I beg to report that I have endeavoured to deal with this matter altogether through the hands of the Rt. Rev. Bishop McNally of Calgary, who has control of the schools in his diocese.

I have formed the opinion that probably the religious order that runs the school would like to get independent action, and my impression is somewhat confirmed by this letter of Mr. MacKie's. Our policy is of course contingent upon our receiving grants from Parliament, and as yet the proposed arrangement is in embryo. Our present idea is to close the High River school, to sell the property, repurchase another, and later on erect a new building. You directed Mr. Graham this morning to examine land in the Claresholm district, but that is as far as the matter has gone.

Regarding the installation of baths and sanitary arrangements at the Roman Catholic school on the Blood reserve, concerning which His Lordship Bishop McNally spoke to the Minister, this is a very old building, almost beyond all usefulness for the purpose of a boarding school. Trane Bellows Radiator Traps

These traps are made by Trane especially for use in connection with the Trane System of Vacuum Heating and the Trane System of Vapor Heating. Because of their various features of Bimetallic Pressure Sensitivity, high power, everlasting bellows, etc., they cannot be surpassed for service with efficient vacuum pumps, low radiation losses, and vacuum pumping better and we strongly recommend the use of Trane traps and Trane pumps together.

The design of the Trane traps makes special provision to guard against the difficulties ordinarily encountered due to dirt and scaling in the system. You will be interested to see on the opposite page that the inside of the body is free from rust and corrosion and that there is no accumulation of solid particles. The floor of the body is perfectly smooth; the bellows does not obstruct the inlet valve right at the trap body and the bellows are never clogged.

The bellows screws up tight in the body and has a one-piece plunger. And by making the body of brass instead of iron, no removable seat is necessary and absolute uniformity is secured. The bellows in Trane traps are, therefore, interchangeable. See Professor Wolf's tests on page 6.

A study of curves below shows exactly what conditions exist in and around the bellows of a Trane trap under any operating conditions of the heating system. They show that the curve of the bellows in the traps follows the steam curve closely, except that it limits it by the fixed constant of 6.7 pounds. That is, the reserve power is always the same. It is balanced. It does not vary throughout the entire operating range. No matter what the pressure difference between the steam and the water at the point of closing is in proportion to it so that the difference is very slight, START, or BABY, or even very high low vacuums do not harm them. That is why they stand the various tests described on the next page.

**TESTS**

**Professor Wolf's Tests — Precision**

In March, 1925, Professor Wolf, of Lewis Institute, Chicago, conducted a series of tests on the Bellows Radiator Trap. Professor Wolf was in charge of the Chicago chapter of the National Association of Building Owners and the present tests were made with the same equipment that was used on the original tests and all conditions were paralleled.

Quoting from Prof. Wolf's official report, note the method used for selecting the traps to be tested:

"The tests were made by connecting the traps to a radiator and subjecting them to various pressures and temperatures. The tests were made under conditions which would be encountered in actual use."

The first test was made for four hours; the second and third tests were for three hours. Pressure and vacuum were varied, respectively, as follows, 9", 10", 6" and 0" Hg.

Throughout the tests the radiator delivered perfectly normal heat without any loss whatever.

The trap was at all times steam tight. It functioned perfectly throughout the tests.

At the end of his interesting report, Prof. Wolf said:

"We have here an example of the possibility of the Bellows Trap being used in the future. We believe that the Bellows Trap will prove to be the greatest advance in the field of radiator traps since the development of the automatic radiator valve."

Blueprints of the exact test data, along with a copy of Prof. Wolf's report, will be gladly furnished to anyone upon request. Besides serving as a valuable reference book, these tests serve also as an excellent illustration of the Trane Bellows Radiator Trap.

**The Mechanical Breakdown Tests — Permanence**

To answer questions that sometimes arise regarding the number of times a bellows will open and close before breaking we have at various times subjected our traps to tests with a machine that opens and closes them mechanically. In addition to these tests, over (20,000,000) complete operations have been made. We have found that the traps do not show signs of weakening, to say nothing of reaching the point where they would break. To keep the bellows would be required to give up a heating system that is reliable, and that's why the bellows are referred to as "permanent." The number of operations the bellows will stand is not particularly remarkable, but the fact that the elastic limit of the Trane metal permits a movement of over 3000 times without failure between the full opening and closing.

**The Trane Blow Tests — Sensitiveness**

A cut-open Trane bellows trap is connected to an air line and subjected to varying pressures. After the trap has been allowed to warm up, the blow is applied, causing the bellows to expand and close the outlet. Now slowly emptying lightly on the blow, the trap is just enough to keep the bellows in actual contact with the pipe. The blow instantly causes the bellows to fully open the outlet. Stop blowing and the trap again closes.

All standard Trane radiator traps respond to this simple test for sensitiveness.

**The University Tests — Durability**

In 1924 a large number of standard Trane traps were tested at the request and under the supervision of Ford Motor Co. engineers. The traps were subjected to a pressure of 75 pounds, and then the temperature was raised until the water vaporized. This was repeated at a steam pressure of 75 pounds. After that the traps were subjected to a vacuum of 25 inches. They were found to be functioning perfectly, showing no difference in leakage or in operating in any kind.

Trane Quick and Float Vent Valves

TRANE Vent Valves are extensively used for ventilating traps, pipe coils, indirect radiators, vento heaters, blast coils, pump tanks, discharge lines, and, in fact, wherever condensate and positive venting valves of large capacity are required.

The Quick and Float Vent Valves are designed with full "T" venting area to assure the quick and easy escape of air from the system. Their thermostatic member is the Trane bellows, similar to the bellows used in Trane radiator traps. Consequently, vent results on the bellows are far superior to those given by the traps, and equally applicable to the vent valve. The vent valves have all the same features of long life, great operating power, balanced pressure, wide opening range, etc. The venting area that is three to four times larger than that of the vent coil capacity is more than ample for all practical purposes, and one Trane vent frequently serves where two or more would ordinarily be required.

All Trane vent valves are equipped with a simple and highly efficient vacuum check. This is a light aluminum disc resting on a knife seat just above the venting port. It offers practically no resistance to the escape of air and at the same time prevents air from passing back into the system. This check is easily accessible for inspection by removing the knurled top cap.

The difference between these two valves is that the Quick Vent is designed for service where steam only is encountered. It closes against steam and vents air. The Float Vent, however, is designed to operate against either steam or water, or both, and vent air. When water is used, use a Float Vent.

The Quick Vent Valve weighs 2 pounds net; it is 2¾" in diameter and 4½" high overall.

The Float Vent Valve weighs 1¾ pounds net; it is 4½" in diameter and 7¼" high overall.

Both styles are made with rough body, polished all over, with highly polished trimmings.

The Float Vent is all tapped for ¾" connection outside and can be shipped tapped for ¼" connection inside if desired.

Trane Direct Return Traps

BROKEN BOILERS AND TRANE DIRECT RETURN TRAPS ARE NEVER FOUND ON THE SAME JOB

THE Trane Direct Return Trap is primarily a safety device. Its function is to return water to the boiler under conditions that prevent condensation. The trap was placed on the market seven years ago as standard equipment in all Trane Radiator Trap Vapor Heating Systems. See page 12. The Trane trap sealing system is safe without one.

Practically all devices on the market offered for this kind of service are complicated and expensive, so much so that they cannot be used on ordinary closed heating systems. They either have tilting tanks with a number of stuffing boxes, screws, etc., or a float on the inside of the tank operating through a stuffing box mechanism consisting of two or more valves on the outside of the tank.

The Trane Direct Return Trap does away with these complications. The mechanism is positive and dependable in operation. It is simple, compact, and efficient in construction, with no stuffing box, tilting tank, or other parts protruding on the outside of the tank, and is offered at a price that makes it possible to use a Trane Direct Return Trap on almost any installation without materially increasing the cost of the job and at the same time without making it complex or requiring the attention of a skilled mechanic.

How the Trane Direct Return Trap Operates

On any radiator trap heating system where the traps function properly and do not leak steam, it is easy to have two pressures on the supply line. One pressure will be on the supply side and the other will be on the return side. Without a Direct Return Trap this difference in pressure would not be enough to prevent the return of condensation by gravity and the loss of heat.

Consider figure 1 in the outline drawing on the next page, in conjunction with the sectional view of the Direct Return Trap shown here. In this diagram there is indicated so that if there is steam generated in excess of requirements, steam will fill the boiler supply line and radiators up to the point A. This A represents the radiator traps. Most good radiator traps pass only air, water, and gases, it is easy to secure higher pressure in the boiler than in the traps.

Notice in the figures that air is vented through a Float Vent Valve, C, and during the high pressure periods water of condensation will flow through the check valve, No. 3, into the Direct Return Trap, D. This Direct Return Trap is at the same pressure as the return line, 4, because it is connected through the vent opening in the top of the boiler into the return line. When the water will rise up into the body of the Direct Return Trap, lifting the float until it reaches the top, stopping the vent connection, stops the supply, E, and closes the vent connection. There will then be the same pressure in the Direct Return Trap as in the boiler. When the water has lowered, due to gravity, since the Direct Return Trap is 5 inches above the water line of the boiler back into the boiler through its second check valve. When the water has lowered to the bottom of the Direct Return Trap, the float slides down the guide rod, opening the vent mechanism to operate, closing the check valve and opening the vent connection so that the water in the returns will again flow into the Direct Return Trap, and the operation will again be repeated.

The Trane Direct Return Trap therefore makes Trane Vapor Heating Systems absolutely safe by providing a positive method of putting water back into the boiler regardless of how carelessly the plant is handled. The Direct Return Trap operates only when the pressure in the boiler is higher than needed to keep water from over a heating plant seeing that water is always returned to the boiler under any and all operating conditions.

Trane Damper Regulator

The damper regulator has been a much neglected part of modern vapor heating systems. In the past several years, heating systems that were designed before vapor was developed did not need dampers. They operated at constant pressure instead of constant temperature. Dampers were given "free" with the system, but they were considered a part of the system's accessories, and therefore there was no incentive on the part of the manufacturer to develop regulators as would have been done had the dampers been sold on a competitive basis.

Since an ordinary steam damper regulator does not work on any vapor system, The Trane Company developed the Sensi-Stat Steam Regulator. This device has proven so effective that hardly no changes have been made in its design.

The body of the regulator is made of cast iron, finished with black paint. The diaphragm is made of rubber. The life of the diaphragm is practically unlimited because it is constantly wetted so that the rubber is constantly in water—a preservative. This is not fat water; no water or steam from the boiler can come into contact with the diaphragm, pressure being transmitted indirectly.

Operation of the regulator is simplified to the barest minimum. The arm is adjusted (by weight), as illustrated, that is adjusted to meet different requirements, and then locked in adjustment, and the bar may be calibrated to show the exact location for the arm to keep the heating system operating at any predetermined pressure.

Due to the arrangement of forces the regulator has an 8 to 1 ratio, the end of the arm moving eight times as far as the plunger that actuates it. This gives the operator ample movement to open and close dampers and check dampers.

Regulators are available in two sizes, the No. 1 Sensi-Stat, with a diaphragm 10 inches in diameter; and the No. 2 Sensi-Stat, effective, with a diaphragm 13 inches in diameter. Because of these large diaphragms an ounce change of boiler pressure will move the control rod and is sufficient to reverse the action of the drafts and check dampers.

Instructions for installing and operating the regulator are packed in each crate.

Trane Vapor-Vacuum Gauge

Trane gauges are standard boiler equipment—for testing both vapor and vacuum. They are finished with black paint and glass front. The dials are marked with black lettering. The scale is graduated in inches. The gauge is made of brass, with a vacuum connection so they do away with making pits for boilers, save difficult basements, and make possible the placing of radiation on the floor or walls of buildings where it is most efficient.

In saving the boiler pit alone, they pay for a good service for pits add considerable economy to the ordinary heating installation and boiler pits are hard to find and hard to clean. Furthermore efficiency is very apt to be reduced through dirt.

As a rule it costs but very little money in actual cost, to install a new condensation pump and the increased cost is more than offset by the greater efficiency and more dependable operation of the heating plant.

A Trane Condensation Pump unit consists of a water storage tank, or receiving tank, a pump, a motor, and an automatic float switch to control operation. Pump and motor are direct connected and mounted on a base as shown in Figure 17. Once installed they operate automatically and require no attention other than periodic attention to see that the pump and motor bearings have sufficient oil.

These pumps are a development of long experience with, and an intimate knowledge of, exact conditions. They are also durable in construction, economical and efficient in operation, and made of materials which, in years, they have convincingly proven their exceptional fitness for dependable, long-term service.

The entire line of Trane Condensation, Circulating, Vacuum, and Pressure pumps are described fully in Trane Bulletin 50. Additional information and recommendations for special applications will gladly be given on request.
The Trane Radiator Trap System of Vapor Heating

The Trane Radiator Trap System of Vapor Heating is designed for buildings of all sizes. It can be adapted perfectly to the requirements of residences, apartments, schools, churches, hospitals, banks, greenhouses, factories, etc.

The boiler equipment includes the Trane Direct Fire Boiler Trap, Trane Damper Regulator, Trane Vacuum Pump, and Trane Vapor-Vacuum Gauge. Radiator equipment includes the Trane Pressureless Valve and a Trane Automatic Vent. Each radiator trap for each radiating unit is practically self-contained and is designed to operate on the principle that the amount of pressure it can maintain is determined by the comparatively high pressures of ten or even twenty pounds. The system is practically carefree and has a distinctly desirable feature that is not found in a vapor heating system, namely, that no air is vented into the rooms. The system is absolutely noiseless and does not affect the building.

The system is economical because it is so nearly automatic in operation. The instant the valve on one of the radiators senses the pressure in the boiler is increased, the valve opens on the sensing radiator, tending to close the draft and slow down the fire, thus saving coal. The instant extra warmth is needed, the valve opens on another radiator, allowing more steam to circulate through the building, and at such times there starts to rise from the water in the boiler it circulates freely. Thus the Trane System, practically at the press of a thumb, warms the entire building uniformly and quickly. A slight stirring of the fire in the boiler will transfer its warmth to the rooms almost before the operator can descend the stairs.

The Trane Vapor System has the feature of natural vaporization. It heats quickly but cools slowly. The Trane System is under vacuum, which means less air resistance, and therefore heat circulates more rapidly, and therefore heats the building more quickly. Also, when the system is shut off, the Trane Vacuum, water boils at lower temperatures, and therefore even when the fire goes down, steam vapor continues to go to the radiators where it will be slow to cool as compared to the rapidity with which it was heated.

The vacuum referred to here is the vacuum caused by the Trane Vacuum Pump. It is not created by a pump or other artificial means. It is an enchained vacuum system using Trane Vacuum Pumps, are practically self-acting.

All Trane Systems are fully guaranteed in every way. Additional details will gladly be sent upon request.

A Typical Piping Layout for a Trane System of Vapor Heating

The layout above illustrates some of the basic engineering principles applied to the design of every Trane System, whether for residences or larger buildings of any kind. Note how the equally balanced circuits running each way from the boiler supply the large piping which illustrates the vapor made in the boiler and distributed to the radiators. The air and water return shown in the other piping runs in the same direction and is practically self-acting.

When properly worked out this feature gives the same effect as though each radiator were placed at such a height that the air would be forced up by gravity through the Radiator Traps and return piping to a point near the boiler, where the air is removed by the Direct Return Trap.

When fire is started in the boiler, the small amount of water soon becomes heated and the vapor rises through the Radiator Traps to the top of the radiators, displacing the air which is heavier than the vapor. The air, together with the water condensed in the traps, is removed automatically by gravity through the Radiator Traps and return piping to a point near the boiler, where the air is removed by the Direct Return Trap.

As the water in the boiler becomes hot, the vapor is condensed and the pressure in the boiler begins to rise. It is then that the sensitive vapor gauge indicates the pressure and opens the traps, preventing fuel waste and ensuring just the amount of pressure necessary for perfect comfort under all weather conditions.
The Trane System of Vacuum Heating

FOR LARGE OR IRRREGULAR BUILDINGS AND BUILDINGS WITHOUT BASEMENTS

The Trane System of Vacuum Heating can be used to correctly heat any building, new or old, large or small. It is particularly adapted to large buildings, in central heating projects, and in greenhouse, schools, hospitals, etc., where there are special requirements to be provided for.

A Typical Installation of a Trane Vacuum system in its simplest form would be similar to the one shown at the right. The boiler and a Trane Return Line Vacuum Pump would be installed instead of a Direct Return Trap. Other heating specialties would be the same, and the radiator specialties consist of the Trane Radiator Supply Valve and the 14-corrosion Trane Bellows Radiator Traps, excepting the Trane Radiator Trap System of Vapor Heating, without vents.

Trane Vacuum Heating offers to large buildings every feature that Trane Vapor Heating gives to the smaller ones. It is, in a sense, Vapor heating with all flexibility and convenience, too irregular to be heated quickly, quietly, uniformly, and efficiently by it; and no heating device made today is more widely used than the most important method of heating.

In addition to the nature of steam temperature control, the Trane Vacuum system has advantages over other types of heating. It overcomes the effect of resistance of air in pipes and the action of gravity. For these reasons, the Trane Vacuum system and return lines can to a great extent be run where convenient rather than in accordance with an exact line of force, increased pipe lift, and other difficulties that cause trouble in an ordinary system and handled by Trane Vacuum with the least cost of labor.

The Trane Vacuum system is as simple if not simpler than a Trane Vapor system to operate.

Steam Temperature Control

One of the special advantages of the Trane System of Vacuum Heating is the steam temperature control. This means that the steam throughout the building can be regulated from the boiler to the individual radiators in any way desired. This is especially desirable in schools, where the temperature varies but it is also highly desirable in many other places.

Re- R.C. School: Blood Reserve.

Dear Mr. Orr:

Replying to your letter of the 29th ultimo, with reference to the lighting fixtures for this school, I have gone over the list submitted by the contractors. I have duly noted your desire to keep the cost of fixtures as near as possible to the allowance of $500.

The list of fixtures suggested by the contractors totals $1042.30 according to their quotation. They also submit a list of suggested additional lights and switches to cost $226.20, thus making a combined total of $1270.50.

I think in some respects the contractors' list is unnecessarily expensive, particularly so in the number of ornate light fixtures included by them.

When the question of lighting fixtures for St. Paul's School came up, I received a letter from Commissioner Graham, enclosing a list of fixtures considered suitable, with approximate prices attached, and I was instructed to follow that list in arranging for the fixtures.

Taking the St. Paul's list as a guide, I have made out a list for this school, with prices in accordance with previous costs, and I respectfully submit it for your consideration.

You will see that the fixtures for outlets shown on the plans come to $565.55, and suggested additional lights, switches, night lights, plugs, etc., costing $324.50, making a combined total of $890.05. This is about $350.00 higher than the St. Paul's job cost, but this is a larger school, with many more outlets. It is $279.55 less than the cost of the lighting fixtures and suggested extras submitted by the contractors.

The prices I have mentioned for the various fixtures in the list I am submitting are not arbitrary; there may be a little fluctuation up and down, but it should average out about as I show.

Regarding the contractors' suggestion of installing telephone desk sets, this seems unnecessary at present as there is no telephone service on the Reserve yet.

With regard to the suggested ventilator fan for the engine room, I do not consider this to be needed, as the engine room will have an outside window, and if we use an automatic plant there will not be very much fumes from the smaller battery that such a plant calls for.

I note that the contractors suggest additional fire gong service to cost $71.50 extra. According to the specifications, (Clause 20, Page 60) "An 8" enclosed type vibrating gong shall be installed in corridor on each
floor and wired to operate from offices on ground floor, and one room on each of the other floors."

The contractors consider that, under this Clause, they are not required to install a fire-gong in either the basement or the 2nd floor, as no "corridor" is shown on the plans for these floors. In my own experience I have not placed fire-gongs in basements. In the case of the 2nd floor, I think that two gongs (6" would do) should be installed, one for the boys and one for the girls, and it may be that the contractors might fairly claim an extra for these. I would suggest, therefore, that the 6" gongs be installed on the ground floor and first floor, as specified, and an additional 6" gong be placed in each of the two divisions of the 2nd floor. Presumably the contractors will be entitled to an extra for the two 6" gongs on the 2nd floor. I shall await your ruling in this matter of fire-gongs before instructing the contractors.

With reference to the general wiring plan, the only fault I have noted so far is that the panel boxes are shown in passages instead of being placed in rooms not accessible to the pupils of the school, as called for in the Specifications. I will have this corrected, and will take pains to see that the Specifications are carried out, and the work done in accordance with the regulations of the Underwriters. I will deal directly with the contractors regarding the wiring plan, which I think you intend me to do.

Your obedient servant

Inspector of Construction.

Gentlemen:

Replying to your wire of July 8th, asking if Trane Traps are entirely manufactured in Canada; we wish to submit the following information.

Our Traps are made in Canada with the exception of the Bellows Element, which is manufacture at our parent Factory in La Crosse, Wisconsin. The Bellows represents approximately 15% of the total cost of the Trap; so we can state definitely that the Trap is 85% Canadian made.

As was pointed out to you by the writer, and to Mr. Orr in our conversation yesterday (July 9th)—the one and only reason why the Bellows are not manufactured in Canada, is because of the very expensive machinery required to produce this high class Element.

We might say however, that it is the intention of the Trane Company to make these Bellows in Canada as soon as the outlook for business warrants the substantial outlay required to commence operations.

The Trane Company have been selling their product in Canada for a good many years, but it was not until 1924 that any great endeavor was made to develop this business here. At that time it was definitely decided that it would be our earnest endeavor to have our goods 100% Canadian made the very moment that it was possible, and we think that you will agree that in view of the fact that our goods are now 85% Canadian Made after only a few months of operation, we have shown some evidence of our intentions.
We are very sorry that our Traps could not be approved for the Indian School, but we trust that you will keep us in mind on future work,—and mention our product in your specifications.

Under separate cover we are forwarding you our bulletin #14, on our product for your information.

Sir:

With reference to the water supply system at the new R.C. School on the Blood Reserve, I understand that it is your intention to erect a water tower similar to that installed at the St. Paul's School. If this is your intention I would be glad to know, as I think the work should be done while the contractors are on the ground. Last year this work was done a little late in the season, when it might just as well have been done in good building weather.

I notice that the Inspector, Mr. Gardner Smith, has been communicating direct with the contractors on this matter, in fact has been giving them instructions as to how they should go about the work. This is contrary to my understanding with the Department and the Minister, and it seems to me an odd way of doing Government business. I would be glad to know if I have got to secure information in this way in order to carry on the work. The Minister informed me on more than one occasion that all matters pertaining to buildings would be dealt with by the Department through this office. I am not finding fault with Mr. Gardner Smith in the least; he should not be found fault with, but I certainly am finding fault with the Department for the way they are doing business and the position in which they have placed me.

Re- R.C.School: Blood Reserve.

Dear Mr.Orr:

Yesterday our job was visited by Mr.D.D.Smith, head
of the firm of Smith Bros. & Wilson, Ltd. the general contractors
for this building.

We had a frank discussion of many matters pertaining
to the work, and prospective auxiliary services, and he again
raised the point about plastering the interior surfaces of the
external basement walls.

You will recall that I wired you sometime ago stating
the contractors did not propose to strap and metal-lath these
concrete surfaces, and I pointed out that if such were done it
would cause a jog, or offset, of about an inch at the top of these
concrete walls where the tile commences. I received a telegram in
reply asking that the specifications be followed, said telegram
being signed by Mr.Mackenzie.

Mr.Smith is very much averse to using metal lath and
strapping on these concrete surfaces. He claims that not only
would it be a waste of money, and an expense that was not figured,
but he thinks it would prove positively detrimental. He insists
that no dampness,or frost, will come through the 16" of concrete
in a heated basement, that he has never known it to do so even in
the severe Regina climate, and that it will never do so here. There
would be a splay in the basement walls at the top of the concrete
where the tile commences, and that a crack would inevitably result
at the union point of the two surfaces, and that looseness of the
plaster would result. Also, he claims, the lower basement walls
would be much more substantial and proof against abuse, particularly
in the play-rooms, if the plastering is done direct on the concrete.

I promised Mr.Smith that I would write you fully on the
subject, passing on the arguments he has raised, and would await
your reply before insisting that strapping and metal lath be
used in plastering on the concrete walls.
I may say that after weighing the evidence I am inclined to concur in the contractors' view, and I think it improbable that any dampness or frost would come through to the inner surface of these walls, especially as only about 12" of concrete wall comes above grade.

The contractors contend that the section drawing shows these walls to be 16" concrete, and that if the intention had been to use strapping and metal lath, such treatment would have been indicated on the section, and that the concrete walls in such case should have been shown at least one inch less in order to have an even vertical surface for the basement plastering.

I shall await further instructions from you on the subject, and shall order the work done in accordance with same.

Your obedient servant

DIARY FOR MONTH OF JULY 1925

1 Dominion Day. Observed as a holiday. No work done at school job.

2 Fine hot day. A start was made at pouring footings, 1 to 4 mix.

3 Fine & hot. Pouring of footings cont'd. Steel placed for columns.

4 Fine & hot. Footings cont'd. I condemned gravel as too dirty, and insisted on cleaner gravel. In aft. some better quality was hauled.

5 Fine day. Sunday. I spent day at job supervising cleaning of well.

6 Hot day. Footings & column finds. cont'd. Carpenters set up forms.

7 Rained last night. Work resumed at 10:30 A.M. Footings cont'd. I still complained of dirty gravel, and objected to shiplap.

8 Fine day. Good quality gravel hauled today. Footings cont'd. We placed 22 steel bars of 3/4" in chimney footings of boiler chimney.

9 Fine day. Start made on concr. walls of main bldg. Bricks and gravel hauled. Carpenters set up forms in sub-cellar.

10 Very hot. Concrete walls & footings cont'd. Com. Graham called.

11 Hot & sultry. Concrete changed to 1 to 5. Issued 1st certificate.

12 Hot day. Sunday. Spent day getting out plans & specs. for Agency water, light & sewage services. Confirmed with Com. Graham.

13 Very hot. 3 bricklayers started work. Poured concr. in sub-cellar.

14 Very hot. Mr. East of Saskatoon, & Mr. Johns of Regina called, and we made another examination of condemned c.i. columns.

15 Very hot. Gravel & bricks hauled. Mr. Johns & I conferred on proposed auxiliary services. Bricklaying & concrete cont'd.

16 Very hot. Bricklaying cont'd on N.wing. We placed 20 4" steel bars in footing of bakery chimney.

17 Hot & windy. Concrete lintels & stone course set up in main bldg.

18 Cooler today. Bricklaying cont'd. Window frames set up.

19 Fine day. Sunday.

20 Fine day. Bricks, I-beams & gravel hauled. Brickwork, digging rear footings, pouring concrete, assembling window frames; cont'd.

21 Fine day. Brickwork of main bldg (N.wing) finished to basement ht.

22 Showery day. Contractors lost 5 hrs. Teams hauled gravel.

23 Fine day. 56/100" rain fell in past 2 days. Plumber arrived. Cement & bricks hauled. Brickwork & concrete work cont'd.

24 Fine day till 4 P.M. when a thunderstorm stopped work. Steel was erected in basement. Brickwork & concrete cont'd.

25 Fine day. 2 more bricklayers started work. Bricks, cement & gravel were hauled. Conc. poured around boiler room & garage.

26 Fine day. Sunday.

27 Fair day. Bricks, gravel & tile were hauled. Joists set up in gr. floor of N.Wing. A start was made laying sub-floor.

28 Fine day. Steel in dining room set up. Sub-floor laid. Brickwork in S.wing commenced. Lumber hauled. I worked at water tower plan.

29 Fine hot day. Brickwork in S.wing cont'd. Painter primed frames.

30 Hot day. Brickwork to basement height in S.wing finished. Plumber laid basement drains in N.wing. Sub-floors & priming frames cont'd.

31 Very hot. I gave basement drain water test, and after leaks were stopped, I approved same. Brickwork & carpentry cont'd.

Sir:-

On the 30th of July I wrote to you with regard to the lighting fixtures for the new R.C. School on the Blood Reserve. Previous to writing this letter I had received one from Mr. Gardner Smith, saying that he had taken the matter of lighting fixtures up direct with you, that you had replied giving him the necessary authority, and he in turn took the matter up with me, asking if it met with my approval, and if it did the order would be placed. A most absurd situation. I understand from the Minister that all matters pertaining to repairs and charges in buildings are to be submitted through my office. I am not so much interested in his reports as I am in the expenditures that he asks the Department to incur. Dear Sir:

Re: R.C. School: Blood Reserve.

I had a call yesterday from Rev. Father Rudaw, Principal and Rev. Father Lebris, Parish Priest of Lethbridge and they requested me to bring to your kind attention several additions to the plan of this building that they are desirous of having provided. I shall take the requests in the order in which they were made.

First—They are anxious to have a standpipe in boilerroom for fire protection. They also suggest that the standpipe be carried up into the chapel. This protection should not prove expensive, as connection could readily be made with the water main in basement. This seems a reasonable request, and has been done elsewhere, under my supervision. A boiler-room is perhaps the greatest source of fire hazard, and the standpipes provided in the specifications for the main building is insufficient to give fire protection in the areas referred to.

Secondly—The Rev. Principal would like rear balconies installed similar to what was provided for the school at Duck Lake. These are for the use of the Sisters, and for apprentices. I spent some time with them studying the plan of this school, and I came to the conclusion that there would be serious architectural difficulties in building similar balconies here on account of the position the fire escape will occupy where attached to this building, and which could cut up the balconies in such a way as would render them almost useless for the purpose intended. As our fire-escapes are probably now made, it would be a big expense to alter them, or turn them in other directions.

An alternative would be to build the balconies at the rear of the wings, giving access to them from the first floor. The Rev. Principal says the balconies would be even more satisfactory if placed there, instead of in the rear centre of the building as was done at Duck Lake. By referring to the last floor plan of this building you may be able to follow better. In the boys' wing, you will observe, there are three rear windows. The centre window could be displaced by a glass door from Nurse's Room, giving access to the proposed balcony; and the window thus displaced could be placed in the wall of Infirmary to give more light there. In the girls' wing there are three windows in the Dormitory, and one of these could be similarly displaced by a door giving access to the other balcony, or if considered necessary to obtain sufficient light the displaced window could be placed in what is shown as a solid wall. The question naturally arises as to whether or not the proposed balconies might throw too much shadow on the windows of the class-rooms below, but I think if the undersides of the balconies were painted white to better reflect the light, there should not be a serious objection in this respect. Also, if thought advisable, the balconies could be placed with the floor of same one or two steps higher than the adjoining floor-level, so as to give more clearance to the classroom windows below.

There is ample space at the rear of these wings for balconies similar to what was provided at Duck Lake, and there are no serious architectural difficulties that I can foresee in placing them there. No doubt the contractors will have their cost data on the others, and should be able to give you an immediate quotation in the event of the Principal's request commanding itself to you. It is important however, that an early decision be arrived at, in order that the necessary openings be made in the brickwork as the building goes up, and so that the extra doors and frames may be ordered.
Thirdly—The Rev. Principal wishes a wash basin to be placed in one of the vestries. I understand Mr. Faunt has on hand a number of wash basins brought from the Dumbo School, and perhaps one of them might be used to lessen the expense.

Fourthly—The Rev. Principal requests that a wash basin be placed in the Principal's bedroom. I have just received a quotation of $158.00 from the contractors for this proposal, as per their letter, which I am enclosing.

Fifthly—The Reverend Principal is desirous of having a stairway provided for the choir gallery in Chapel, similar to what was built at Duck Lake. He points out that the Sisters and others who may be in the choir gallery, under the present plan, would have a long walk through the school in order to come to the altar for Communion, and then a long round-about trip back again. He says it is essential that this be avoided, and that a small stairway from the gallery to the Chapel floor be provided.

I promised the Reverend Fathers that I would promptly bring their requests to your attention, and would be guided by your instructions in all these matters.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

"E. Gardner Smith"

Dear Sir:-

I beg to inform you that I am told that the plumbing specifications provide for no Hot Water Circulating Line. Its omission would mean a considerable waste of water, owing to the fact that when hot water faucets are turned on, the water would have to run for some time before hot water would reach the fixture. This waste would occur at every fixture in the building, and in the aggregate would mean a serious waste, and for the distant fixtures the water would seldom come really hot. A hot water circulating line going back to the heating boilers, and jacket heater, would insure hot water reaching the fixtures at once when the faucets are turned on. To get the full efficiency from the suggested hot water circulating line it should be covered like a steam main with air cell covering. The contractors have quoted a price as follows:

"To install hot water circulating line, and cover hot water mains and risers to the point where branches are taken off for the fixtures, with 2" air cell covering for the sum of $418.00. If 1" air cell covering is used it would cost $434.50." You will remember that it was necessary to install such a system in the Edmonton School and I was told that the plumbing is not efficient without a hot water circulating line.

No range boiler is provided in the kitchen in this school. In the summer months it will be necessary to depend on the jacket heater for hot water. If a range boiler were provided there would always be a generous supply of hot water on hand heated by the kitchen fire, and only on special occasions such as laundry day, would it be necessary to fire the jacket heater. The Contractors offer to

Sir:

Mr. Gardner Smith, Inspector of Construction at the new R.C. School on the Blood Reserve draws attention to one or two matters of extra expenditure, authority for which I would like to secure from the Department.

Mr. Gardner Smith points out that the hot-water storage tank provided in the specifications will be heated by live steam from the heating-boilers during the heating season. There should be a "hot-water temperature control" attached to this storage tank in order to prevent excessively hot water from passing through the hot-water lines in the building. If it is omitted there will be times when live steam will come through when the faucets are opened, with danger of scalding the attendants. Also, there will be continuous trouble from leaking taps owing to the steam destroying the washers. At St. Paul's school asked for authority to install a temperature-control attachment, but it was refused at the time, and they are having the trouble that I have indicated. A "Powers' Automatic Temperature Control" costs about $120.00 installed, and by its use the temperature of the water in the storage tank can be prevented from exceeding a pre-determined temperature. It works on the thermostat principle, and automatically shuts off the steam when the required temperature of the water is reached, and admits the steam again as the temperature falls. I would recommend that this Automatic Temperature Control be provided.

A small pump and storage tank should be placed in the laundry for the purpose of drawing a supply of soft water from the large concrete cistern outside. The contractors were asked to quote, and give a figure of $390.00. Mr. Gardner Smith, however, has received quotations for pumps from Bruce Robinson Distributors, Ltd., of Calgary and McAuley-Bell & Morse of Calgary. The Bruce Robinson Distributors pump will cost installed $315.00; it operates automatically, controlling the flow of water. The other pump quoted on by McAuley-Bell and Morse is a Hoosier Horizontal pump the cost of which installed would be $145.00. It however lacks the automatic features of the other and would occupy more floor space. I would recommend the installation of the automatic pump.
