Dear Sir,

As there has been a considerable amount of controversy between your Inspector, Mr. E. Gardner Smith, and ourselves with reference to the Coal Bin, we are explaining our position to you in this matter.

In the first place, on July 11th last we received an order which read as follows: "Enlarge coal bin to the same size and type as the one at St. Paul's school, with reinforced slab roof, with two rings and covers for receiving the coal. Exact size of enlarged coal bin will be given in a separate letter. Means of payment will also be separately explained." But we have nothing further in our files to show what the means of payment would be, so that we had no way of counteracting the idea that we were going to put all the concrete in the building 4-to-1. It developed later that Mr. E. Gardner Smith expected us to offset largely the cost of this addition by a saving in cement.

At the time we received the order, we already had the coal chutes ordered and on the site, and the smaller coal room excavated, and the surplus earth piled all around, and we had to do the balance of the excavation in a more or less disorganized manner.

On December 5th we submitted our cost for additional work on the coal room, which amounted to $683.65. This price did not include the additional work on the Chimney, and we were to give the Department credit for cement saved due to the change from 4-to-1 to 5-to-1. The main difficulty arises over how much cement we saved. At the date the order was forwarded, we had a large amount of footings and walls run, but this can easily be estimated. The main difficulty is that we do not consider that the specification for the footings or the rough concrete of the basement floors calls for a 4-to-1 mixture. At the same time we realize that no particular mix was called for, and in estimating this school we actually figured on a 6-to-1 concrete, which is quite usual for footings and the rough concrete for a basement floor, and we think that most contractors reading the specifications would have figured on a similar basis, as it would be strong enough for the work and would make a good job. On the other hand, it is quite usual to put walls in stronger than footings, and we certainly figured on the walls being a 6-to-1 mix if gravel was used. We realize that the Department may have a different understanding than ourselves regarding this matter, but the fact remains that in making up our cost we only figured on putting a good grade of concrete in the basement floors and footings, consistent with the work we usually turn out; and if we give the Department credit for a saving in cement on the footings and rough concrete floors, we shall be giving them a credit for something which we never charged them for in the first place. As far as the walls are concerned, we expect and always expected to allow the Department a credit equal to approximately 1 sack of cement per cubic yard of all the concrete poured into the walls after the date of the order; and as the basement and approximately half of the main building walls
were run prior to the order, we consider there has been approximately 160 cubic yards of concrete run in walls on which a saving in cement could be expected.

We have no complaint to make as to Mr. Smith's attitude, because we believe that he is interpreting the specifications to the best interests of the Department which he represents; but there certainly is room for another interpretation because a careful perusal of the specifications will show that Clause #7, page 16, "Footings", and clause #12, page 17, "Concrete Floors", leave the question of mix open; whereas clause #9, page 16, "Walls", clearly defines the proportions for this part of the work, and it simply boils down to a question of whether we were justified in figuring the footings and rough concrete under the basement floors of a good standard mix, or whether we should have figured them the same proportion as the walls.

In considering this matter, we do not think a comparison should be made between this and the coal room at St. Paul's, as in the latter case the contractors had the opportunity of saving right from the start, and further they may have made arrangements to put the concrete down even more, and without being informed on all the particulars of the matter, it would be impossible to compare them on a fair basis.

We think this explanation covers all the trouble involved, and will enable you to make a decision. At the same time, we wish to express our regret that it has been necessary to bring the matter to your attention.

Yours very truly,

SMITH BROS. & WILSON LTD.

Sir:-

With reference to the change in cement proportion in the concrete for this building, which was authorized by you on the occasion of your visit here on July 11th, it was plainly stated that this saving in cement was to be applied towards paying for the cost of the enlarged coal-bin.

There has been an interchange of statements and letters between the contractors and me on this feature of the work with regard to the cost of the enlarged coal-bin, and also the cost of building the enlarged chimney from the heating boilers. I have accepted the contractors' figures for the chimney, and I think we are in agreement regarding quantities of cement used throughout, but in one important particular we have not been able to agree. I take the view that the change in cement proportion applies to footings, walls and sub-floors which were placed subsequent to July 11th. In the cement specification of 1 to 4, no authority can be found for interpreting this in any other way than for all concrete—at least that is my view. Mr. Johns takes the view that only on walls does the specification of 1 to 4 apply, and he does not admit that the Department is entitled to any saving in the change in mix to 1 to 5 except on walls.

Nothing can be gained by further correspondence between the contractors and me on this feature of the work; it is now a question of a ruling as to whether my interpretation of the specification is right, or whether Mr. Johns' interpretation is right. I do not wish to make an arbitrary decision without first consulting you, so am enclosing copies of recent correspondence with the contractors on the subject for your information, and it is possible that you may wish to hear their statement of their case before issuing instructions to me in the matter.

I have no wish other than to deal fairly with the contractors, with whom I have had harmonious relations throughout the work, and I think it is simply an honest difference of opinion in our respective readings of the specifications.

I am withholding an overdue Certificate on extra work until I receive your ruling on this matter in which the contractors and I hold divergent views.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Rev. Sir,

I beg to quote from a letter received from the Lister Co., Ltd., of Canada, who installed the electric lighting plant at the new Blood School.

"We have finished the installation of the 5 and 6 K.W. plants at the Blood Reserve, Cardston, Alberta, and everything is working in fine shape and satisfactorily, with one exception. The man who they have appointed as attendant on this plant is certainly not qualified for the looking after of this equipment. We do not mean that our plant is so complicated that it needs a qualified engineer to look after it, but in this case he is a man that has never had any connection whatever or experience with gasoline engines and, therefore, not in a position to readily put right any small or minor troubles which are always cropping up with a gasoline engine. We want to see these plants giving satisfaction, and we certainly are going to give all the service possible which we can, but if the different organizations which are looking after these plants will not place a man who has had some experience in charge, they cannot expect to get results with any equipment."

You will notice from the contents of their letter that they state that the man in charge of the lighting plant is not competent to look after same. If this lighting plant and other mechanical equipment about the building is to be properly operated it is necessary that a man fully qualified be put in charge.

I am sending a copy of the Lister Company's letter to Mr. Fount.

Sir:

Mr. E. Gardner Smith reports from Cardston that the kitchen flue in the chimney at the R.C. School will not draw properly when the wind is in a certain quarter, that in fact the smoke will sometimes return and blow out into the rooms below, a condition which is not only extremely unpleasant, but interrupts the work of the institution.

Mr. Gardner Smith attributes the trouble to the proximity of the large flat-roof area where the wind blowing around this area inside of the coping walls seems to create a contrary draft.

He suggests as a remedy the raising of the chimney, and to be quite safe recommends adding six feet. He has procured a tender for raising the chimney four feet at a price of $115.00, and raising it six feet at a price of $145.00.

In view of Mr. Gardner Smith's report I would recommend that action be taken to raise the chimney, and if authority is granted competitive prices for the work would be procured.

Dear Mr. Faunt:

Regarding your inquiries concerning the qualifications of Mr. Harvey Cline, the engineer at the above school, I would say that so far he seems to be handling the heating and lighting plants satisfactorily.

I believe his principal experience has been with steam boilers rather than with electric plants. His qualifications for looking after the heating boilers, and the high pressure laundry boiler, are satisfactory to the Provincial Boiler Inspector, who was here last month, and who expressed his satisfaction in this respect.

The Lister-Bruston Power and Lighting Plant is new to the engineer, and he does not claim to be an expert on electric generating apparatus. However, he had the advantage of being here when the plant was being installed, and received instructions at first hand from Lister's mechanic. Since then he has been in full charge of the plant, and appears to be carefully following the directions he received, and so far no trouble has been experienced. He seems a very steady and careful operator, and I can see no reason why he should not be allowed to continue looking after the electric plant.

Yours truly,

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo with reference to outbuildings for the new R.C. Residential School on the Blood Reserve. I note you state that you have not sufficient information on your files to enable you to intelligently decide what is to be done with regard to buildings at this institution.

I would say that only one stable was built at this school. This is a horse barn and if you will refer to my letter of the 30th November last, you will see that I suggested using this building as an implement shed, owing to the distance at which it was situated from the main school building, and an implement shed had to be provided in any event. What is required in addition to this building is a cow barn to accommodate 20 head of cows, and having two calf pens and a feed compartment. This should be a building somewhat similar to the one which we erected at the St. Paul's School, or perhaps a few feet larger. A horse barn to hold ten head of horses is required, also a pigsty and a henhouse. They should also have a shed to house wagons, binders and other large implements in addition to the building above mentioned.

I may say

Duncan C. Scott, Esq.,
Deputy Supt. General of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I may say that in mentioning an amount of $5000.00 for these buildings I did not figure on a pigsty, nor on the stanchions for the cow barn, which latter item will cost in the neighborhood of $500.00. I think, however, that $6000.00 will provide everything that is required there in the way of buildings.

My reason for bringing this matter to your attention at this time is that Mr. Henry George, who has done all our work as Foreman for the last two years is now at the R.C. School putting in shelving, etc., and he would be ready to go right ahead with the outbuildings while he is there. We should buy the lumber in carload lots, and this will have to be ordered some little time ahead. This, of course, is the most economical way to build, as it eliminates contractors profits.

Kindly advise me as soon as possible so that we can go ahead with this work at the earliest possible date.

Yours very truly,

W. M. Graham,

Dear Mr. Orr:

I beg to advise you that I have issued a 12th (final) Certificate for $13,655.20, to Messrs Smith Bros. & Wilson, Ltd. in full payment of the balance due them on the main contract and authorized extras. You will observe I have included the 10% hold-back maintained throughout the job.

I am sending you, under separate cover, a complete Statement of the entire work, including all extras, and am also including invoices, vouchers and time-sheets which have been rendered to me by the contractors. For some of the minor items of extras, the contractors stated that they were unable to furnish time-sheets as the work so overlapped with other work, but in all cases where time-sheets are missing, I have checked up the charges closely, and the amounts charged are not excessive.

Much the largest extra work done on a percentage basis is the Sewage Disposal Works, and I am sending complete time-sheets and invoices for this.

I think the accounts I am sending you are sufficiently vouched, but if there are any items on which you desire further information, I shall be pleased to give further particulars at your request.

The contract has, on the whole, been well performed, and I think the Department has received good value for the amount expended. I am told by the contractors that it has not been a profitable contract for them.

I have had communications from both the Indian Dep't and the Dep't of Labour with reference to a workman's complaint that he had been underpaid. Under these circumstances would it not be advisable to retain a certain sum from the final Certificate in case the contractors' explanations are not acceptable to the Gov't? It is possible that other workmen are awaiting the outcome of the investigation. I wrote the contractors an official letter early in the job notifying them that they would be expected to observe the Fair Wage Schedule in the Specifications.

Sir:-

I have received a letter from Mr. E. Gardner Smith with reference to the tar and gravel roof of the new R. C. School. He reports that a slight leakage was noticed on the 30th of March, which, on investigation, was found to be a result of the buckling of the roof in one or two places, allowing the water from melting snow to find its way through into the dormitory below. Mr. Gardner Smith arranged with Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson to have the roof repaired and although they did this and to the satisfaction of the Inspector, they insisted that the damage was caused through no fault of their's.

This buckling Mr. Gardner Smith attributes to the effect of the wind, which in that locality blows with extreme force and often for days at a time, causing a suction which tends to draw and buckle the roofing thus causing it to crack where the buckling takes place through which water finds its way. He suggests as a remedy against a recurrence of the trouble, which under present conditions he claims is inevitable, the following treatment:

Sweep off loose gravel into piles, then make a heavy pouring (not just a swabbing) of hot pitch. While the pitch is hot, spread a heavy covering of fine and coarse gravel. The pitch must be of sufficient depth to make a bed into which a large quantity of stone can sink and become embedded. In this way the necessary weight can be secured to hold the roofing down and prevent the action of the wind.

If the Department wish to give consideration to the suggestion of Mr. E. Gardner Smith and will so advise me, I will direct him to procure prices for the work indicated.

Dear Sir:

Re R. C. School, Blood Reserve.

With reference to your enquiry from us for the reasons for a charge made by Lister & Co. for extra travelling expenses to install pumping plant at the above school, would say we have made enquiries from the Superintendent we had on the job, Mr. A. Turton. He informs us your Inspector, Mr. Gardner Smith, told him the plant had arrived and he had wired Lister & Co., to that effect, and also to send a man along to install same. At the time Mr. Smith told Mr. Turton this, the man was supposed to be on his way to Dardiston. At that time, neither Mr. Smith nor Mr. Turton had any plan or information as to where this particular part of the plant was to be installed.

On the arrival of the man, it was found that he would have to install his machinery right where our pump was situated, which would mean our pump would have to be disconnected, and no water would be available for about five days. As we were right in the midst of laying concrete floors, it would have meant our shutting down the work and releasing the labor for that number of days. This, of course, was not to be expected from us, consequently the man went back right away and did not come again until he was notified there was nothing to interrupt him proceeding with his installation.

Of course, you fully understand we had nothing whatever to do with the supplying or installing of the plant furnished by Lister & Co., this not being in our contract. We have questioned Mr. Turton very carefully and there is no doubt in our mind as to the truthfulness of his statement. Therefore we cannot accept any liability for any expenses in connection with this account, it being perfectly clear to us that Lister & Co. acted entirely on the instructions from your representative on the job.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 6th inst., with letter enclosed from Messrs. Smith Bros. & Wilson, Ltd., contractors, on the subject of responsibility for Lister's charge of £97.50.

The contractor's statement is inaccurate in saying that, in my wire to Listers telling them their plant had arrived, I had asked them to send their man. I merely notified them of the arrival of their plant at the station, and my reason for doing so was because the contractors' superintendent would have nothing to do with it as his firm were not installing the electric plant, and because storage charges were mounting up. I enclose a copy of my telegram to Listers.

I enclose letters received from Listers, in which they acknowledge the plan of the machinery room which I had sent them. In this letter (Nov. 26th) 24 hours was mentioned as the time it would take to set their engine bases, and Mr. Turton was prepared to shut down for the 24 hours mentioned, but thought power for the pump would then be available from one of the Lister engines. Lister's expert did not arrive until eight days after I sent the telegram, and there was ample time for Mr. Turton to stop him from coming had he thought it necessary.

Lister's man arrived on the 16th December, and then we were informed for the first time that he would require five full days to set up his plant, and that the temporary pumping plant would be in his way and would have to come down. Mr. Turton could not do without water for so long a time, and in consequence Lister's man had to make a second trip.

My responsibility was just in the matter of sending the telegram, and that was simply an act of courtesy. Mr. Turton would undoubtedly have stopped Lister's man from coming so soon had he not gathered from Lister's letter (which I had shown him) that there would only be 24 hours' interruption to the pumping service, but he could not agree to shutting down for five days.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,-

Re- H.C. School; Blood Reserve.

I beg to enclose herewith invoices in triplicate from Mr. F.W. Flett for work and materials supplied at the above school.

The Invoice for $15.00 is for making and installing two gal. iron covers for the cooling tanks of the Lister power and lighting plant. These tanks come open, without tops, and when the engine has run for a time, the tanks discharge steam into the room, which dampens everything within reach. To overcome this, the covers were made, and connected to a vent which discharges the steam outside of the building.

The Invoice for $17.30 is for placing new leather cup-washers in the working barrel of the pump cylinder. Owing to so much sand coming at first with the water, the original leathers were soon destroyed, and only a small quantity of water could be raised, but after providing the new leathers the trouble was overcome. The water is now coming fairly clear, and I do not anticipate much more damage from sand in the water. The original leathers were worn out before the School was occupied.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Sir:-

With reference to Department #103-2-15 dated the 19th ultimo, I am advised by Mr. E. Gardner Smith that he has received an Estimate from Mr. F.W. Flett, Cardston of $1200.00 to re-coat the gravel and pitch roof of the new Blood R.C.School. Mr. Gardner Smith in submitting the quotation states as follows,-

"At first glance this seems a high price, but there are 118.07 squares to this roof, and there should be about 80 lbs. of pitch applied per square, which would call for about 5 tons of pitch. Also there would be several yards of screened gravel in addition to the gravel at present on the roof. The price quoted works out at about $10.00 per square for labour and materials. Mr. Flett is the only competent roofer I know of in the Cardston district. Roofing work of this kind should be done during the warm summer months, and before the heavy fall winds return. I am in receipt of your letter of the 2nd inst., in which you mention that the Department requires a written explanation from me regarding Mr. F.W. Flett's account of $67.80 for the installing of a Flat Work Ironer last May at the above school.

This Ironer was purchased by the Department after the completion of the building contract, and as Mr. Flett was the only man obtainable locally, competent to do steam fitting, he was the logical man to engage. I saw the machine in operation after Mr. Flett had finished his work, and it was working well.

As the heating at this school is a Dunham system, Mr. Flett installed a Dunham trap, for which he charged $32.50. This was required for air elimination and equalization, and is the principal item on his bill. Sir:-

Reporting on the condition of the above boilers after making a thorough inspection and test, I find the boilers in safe working condition as pressure stated on Inspection Certificate; operated with proper care and free from scale and corrosion. However, since these boilers are practically new, it is not to be expected to find dangerous corrosion.

In order that corrosion may be prevented, kindly leave the boilers layed up during the Summer month or such period of un-operation in the following manner, - At the end of each heating Season; boilers are to be emptied and washed out; then dried out internally and left open; until the heating Season resumes; During the heating Season, when only one boiler is required in service, do not operate the same boiler continuous, but divide the Season, so each boiler has its share of operation.

I would call your attention to the Laundry boiler; this boiler is too small for the work it is doing, it oams and primes badly, adding mud to the unsanitary of the operation.

Dear Mr. Scott:-

Sir:

A short time ago, I received a letter from Mr. J. E. Pugh, Indian Agent at Cardston, stating that he had discussed with the Reverend Principal of the St. Mary's R.C. Indian Residential School, the matter of fire escapes at that institution and they appear to be concerned because there is no direct access to the fire escapes from the girls' and boys' dormitories and that in case of fire, they would have to pass at the heads of the main staircases and argue that if there was a fire in the vicinity of the staircases, the children would not be able to get out that way. As a remedy, they suggest that a fire escape be placed in both the dormitories, the exit to which will be through the window of the staff room.

I do not see that the objections are well taken or that there is any necessity for the placing of fire escapes as suggested. The staircases in this school are of steel construction and, therefore, are fireproof, and if the children are properly drilled and taught what to do in case of a fire, the existing fire escapes are, in my opinion, sufficient. I should like, however, to receive an expression of opinion from the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W. W. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dec. 20, 1927.

Sir,

Replying to your letter of the 15th instant, with reference to the fire escape at the St. Mary's School on the Blood Reserve, I agree that it is unnecessary to place additional fire escapes on this building. You are quite right in your statement that the stair cases are of fire proof construction. However, I think it would be advisable to place doors at the top of the stair case on the dormitory floor, in order to prevent smoke from entering the passage through which the pupils have to pass in order to reach the fire escape, as you know there are a lot of mishaps from fire gas to the dense amount of smoke.

Your obedient servant,

Honorable Sir:

In my Estimates for this year 1929, I made application for the building of a separate residence, which would be the home of the school teacher who intends to get married in July or August. No accommodation for married couples exists in the School, which makes it very inconvenient and oblige us to employ only single men. Mr. Coady has been teaching for two years and is giving me and the Department full satisfaction and I would like very much to keep him. The reason of this letter is for me to know if the residence has been granted and is going to be build this Summer; I address it to you directly for this information, as Mr. Coady makes it a point for staying at the School or looking for another position.

Honorable D.C. Scott, Deputy Minister,
Superintendent of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Canada.

Honorable Sir:

I have your letter of the 8th inst. stating that no provision has been made for a separate residence for the School Teacher at the Blood Indian School. I cannot help expressing my disappointment. I had mentioned the matter to you about a year ago, when we met at St. Albert, and considering the fact that it is so difficult to secure a man that will take a real interest in the Indians, Mr. Coady will not accept to live in the School, and in fact it would be very inconvenient for him and for the rest of the Staff. I am informed that appropriation has been voted to build a pig sty and an implement shed for our School this Summer. Could it not be possible to have a residence erected in the place of these other buildings, which would wait for another year. The house may be a little more expensive, but the Department could stand the difference; otherwise, I would be obliged myself to build a separate residence, although my means are very inadequate. Hoping that you will take this matter into consideration, I remain Honorable Sir.

Respectfully yours,

E. Riaux, O.M.T. Principal

The medical officer, in a report on his recent inspection of the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School, states that the pupils do not get a sufficient supply of butter and milk. COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,

REGINA, SASK. December 6th, 1929.

Inspector Christianson's report on schools in Blood Agency.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to report that on my recent inspection of the Blood Agency I also visited the two boarding schools on the reserve.

ST. MARY'S R. C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

The number of children in residence was 108 and 3 were absent, which makes a total of 111. The Principal stated there were about 15 children on the reserve of school age who had not been entered on the roll yet as the parents refused to bring them in. Ways and means of bringing these children in were discussed with the Principal, and the Agent intends to take steps to see that they are placed in the school so as to begin in the January quarter. I also spent a little time in each classroom and found that the grades taught were from 1 to 7.

I wish to state that I was well impressed with the senior teacher, Mr. Cote. From all reports he is an excellent teacher and has a fine influence over the boys.

The school throughout was spotlessly clean and well kept. The same applies to the outside buildings. The buildings, furniture, and machinery are all receiving the best of care and attention.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
ST. MARY'S R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

Last fall the Principal built a new house for Mr. Cote, the teacher, at a cost of approximately $4,000.00, and he expects to be re-imbursed by the Department. Therefore, this amount was placed in the Estimates.

It was also brought to my attention that water was continually draining into the sub-basement. This is used as a storehouse for fruit, canned goods, etc., but is below the basement proper and cannot be drained into the sewer. The existing condition is not very good as there is a smell from the stagnant water. The basement is continually being pumped out, but it is always damp. It will be a difficult undertaking to drain the basement as the drain would have to run out to the coulee, which is a considerable distance from the school, and levels etc. would have to be taken.

There is also the matter of doors in the playroom which I will take up in a special letter.

This school had a very good crop last summer - 3,000 bus. of wheat, 2,500 bus. of oats, 860 bus. of barley, 600 bus. of potatoes, and a lot of other vegetables. They have a nice herd of cattle, raise pigs, and also keep a lot of chickens. The school now supply their own requirements in the way of beef and pork. From 16 to 20 cows are milked, and the children are receiving all the milk they require. Eleven hundred pounds of butter were packed during the summer for the use of the children this winter.

The children looked well and were well clothed, and I am pleased to be able to report that,

as far as
ST. MARY'S R.C. INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL (CONT'D.)

as far as the health of the children is concerned, they look 100% better than they did two years ago.

This matter was discussed and the Agent will see that these children are brought in the first of the year. The building is reported to be clean and in first-class shape. Honorable Sir,

Re St Mary's Ind.Res.School, Cardston.

I beg to refer to your letter No 103-2-5, dated June the 8th 1929, and the reply of Rev.Father E.Ruax, Principal, dated June the 12th 1929. This is in connection with the erection of a cottage for a married teacher. And as the matter at the time was considered very urgent and in the interests of the School, Rev. Father Ruax proceeded with the building last Fall.

Now I take the liberty of submitting this matter again to your consideration, with the object of obtaining a refund of the moneys invested in that building. Although I acknowledge that this was done without your formal approval, nevertheless this question was thoroughly examined and discussed by us, and for the best interests of the School and the Department it was conceded that the cottage should be erected.

The teacher, Mr.Coady, had been teaching at St Mary's School for three years and a half, and during that period had given entire satisfaction to the pupils, to the Indian parents, to the Agent and to the Inspectors. You will agree with me how difficult it is to secure and keep, for a number of years, a real competent teacher on an Indian Reserve. Mr.Coady, about to be married, would not remain on the staff unless he were given convenient quarters, and rooms for him and his wife could not conveniently be set apart in the School building.

I understand that a cottage, costing $4500.00, had been built by the Department at St Paul's School, Cardston, for the Farm Instructor whose wife is also a teacher.

Rev.Father Ruax, the Principal, before undertaking the construction of this cottage for the teacher, submitted the whole matter to Mr.Pugh, the Indian Agent, making him acquainted with all the details of the contract and the cost. Naturally the Indian Agent could not authorize the undertaking, as this belongs entirely to jurisdiction of your Department. Nevertheless Mr.Pugh, residing near the School, was in a position to ascertain the nature of the construction and can now warrant that there was no extravagance and
that we got full value for the $3799.00 spent on this cottage.

I herewith forward copy of the Contract and all the receipted Invoices of work and material paid on this cottage, so that your Department may satisfy itself how the expenses were incurred. I understand that Inspector Mr. Christianson is also well acquainted with the facts and is in a position to report on same.

Moreover, Honorable Sir, you are aware that when the Oblate Fathers took over the management of the new Schools both at the Bloods and the Piegan they were faced with very serious sacrifices regarding the finances. We realize that we are to cooperate with the Department in the respective Indian Institutions. But in the present instance we feel that we should not be called upon to bear this heavy disbursement for an important and necessary improvement at the St Mary's School. It is true that in this particular case we have proceeded without your formal approval, but we had concluded that your authorisation was only delayed and postponed for the time being.

We are fully convinced that you will now favorably take up this matter and see your way to refund to the Oblate Fathers the sum of $3799.00, which we have expended on a cottage which is a credit to the Department and to the School.

Therefore I hope that you will succeed even to include this item of expenditure for the present Fiscal year 1929-1930.

I remain, Honorable Sir,

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]

Honorable Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of April the 2nd with reference to the cottage for a married teacher at the Blood Indian Residential School. I understand perfectly well that the item should have been previously included in your Estimates and the customary authorisation should have been obtained.

If the erection of this cottage was nevertheless proceeded with, it was not in any spirit of contravention with the rules of the Department; but as I stated in my letter we were prompted only by the conviction that it was for the greater interest of the pupils under very pressing conditions.

Although you had no direct control over the erection of this cottage, I have no doubt that you can see by the documents I sent that great care was taken by the Principal as regards plans, specifications and estimate; and also copies of all invoices were secured. Dear Mr. Williams:

I have the honour to report on an inspection made last week at the St. Mary's Roman Catholic School on the Blood Reserve. I might say that I did not inspect the class rooms, as I intend to leave as much of the inside work as I possibly can for the winter months.

I went through the building, and around the grounds, and went into the general management of the institution. This school has gone into farming and cattle-raising quite extensively. At the present time the following acreage is under cultivation: Wheat - 200 acres; Oats - 65 acres; barley - 60 acres; green feed - 40 acres; potatoes 6 acres; garden - 4 acres; and they are summerfallowing about 120 acres, making a total of approximately 500 acres. The crop looked exceptionally well, and no doubt the work on the land is being well performed, as Brother Tom, the Farming Instructor, is an excellent farmer. It will therefore be seen that that part of the work is being properly attended to.

The school owns 205 head of cattle, and 25 head of work horses. The average number of cows milked during the year,...

A. S. Williams, Esq.,
Acting Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
during the year is from 15 to 20. They also keep 400 chickens and between 70 and 100 pigs. All the hams and bacon required for the school are cured on the premises. No cream, butter or eggs are sold, but are used at the school, and all the beef required is slaughtered at the school. Thirty head of cattle were put through the slaughter house last year. The children are obviously very well fed, and with the splendid garden, they receive a great variety of food as well.

At the time of my visit there were 136 children in residence and only one pupil to be discharged during the holidays. There are, however, quite a few to be discharged during the coming winter.

The staff at the school consists of 15 sisters, a Principal, Assistant Principal, one male teacher, an engineer, farming instructor, and two labourers, or a staff of 22 in all. There are three class rooms in the school, one being taught by Mr. Cote, who has been there for a number of years, and the other two by the sisters. I might say that I was in the senior boys' room, which is taught by Mr. Cote, who, I consider, is a very competent teacher and has a good manner of handling the Indian boys, both in and out of the classroom.

The staff have put forth quite an effort to beautify the ground surrounding the school by planting trees and shrubs, &c., and a great improvement has been brought about. However, in this respect, it does not compare with the Roman Catholic School on the Peigan Reserve.

The buildings are all in a good state of repair with the exception of the flooring in the cow stable.

This will......
This will have to be replaced. They have also had considerable trouble with water coming into the sub-cellar in the school, and the cement floor is all broken up. The Principal informed me that he had requisitioned for the cement for the last four years, but it had never been supplied. This I am taking up with the Department in a separate letter.

Another matter which I wish to bring to your attention is that where the top of the outer wall is finished with a cement block, set in about two inches from the outside brick, the two inch thickness is faced with cement. This cement facing is gradually falling off, thus allowing the rain to get through the cement block and through the walls. The cement falling is very dangerous for the children and others around the school. I do not know whether I have made myself clear, but if the Department do not understand what I mean, I shall endeavour to explain it more clearly in a special letter. I do not wish to make any recommendation in connection with repairing this, as in my opinion it would be futile to replace the cement facing, unless we found a more satisfactory method of doing it, as it would only fall off again in time. A well qualified man in that line should be consulted, or our architect at Ottawa might have some suggestions to offer in the matter. I only wish to impress upon the Department that some steps should be taken to deal with this, and if there is anything further I can do in the matter to procure information for the Department, I shall be glad to do so.

From my observations of this institution, I consider that the children are being well looked after.

They are......
They are well clothed and receive an abundance of food, and receive excellent care in every way.

During the winter months I shall inspect the class rooms for my own satisfaction, to show the children that I am taking an interest in their welfare, and I will also go fully into the other fields of endeavour of the staff.

In connection with the outside work the boys of course work on the farm and in the garden, help with the stock raising, &c., and in that way get a fair education in general farm work. During the holidays the girls do the milking, but the rest of the time this work is done by the boys.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

INSPECTOR'S OFFICE.
CALGARY, ALTA.... December 2nd, 1932.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of the St. Mary's Roman Catholic Indian Residential School on the Blood Reserve.

At the time of my visit there were 139 children in residence. I spent considerable time in each of the three classrooms, which are lovely bright rooms and the furniture, which is all in first class shape, is nicely arranged.

The Senior class is taught by Mr. Cote who has been at the school for a number of years, and is an exceptionally good teacher. The other two classrooms are taught by the sisters. As the Public School Inspector inspects the classroom work, I shall not go into detail in this regard. Mr. Bremner was expected there shortly to make his annual inspection. I might say, however, that the work performed in these classrooms seemed to be quite satisfactory, and I am sure the children are making fair progress.

HEALTH:

The health of the children at the school is good. I must say that there has been a great improvement in the appearance of the children during the last few.....

Dr. Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
ST. MARY'S (Continued),—

last few years. I remember Doctor Stone visiting this school with me two or three years ago and at that time he remarked that he was not satisfied with the appearance of the children. This could not be said now, as the children, from a layman's point of view, are in perfect health. This is partly due to the fact that the school is now better off financially than when it was first opened, and they operate quite a farm, raise their own beef, and have an abundance of cream, milk, butter, eggs, &c., and as the children are better fed, their health has naturally improved.

BUILDING:

The interior of the building is in splendid shape. The Department are aware that wherever the Sisters of Charity are in charge of a school, it is always kept perfectly clean and in good condition at all times.

The furniture in every room looks just as good as the day it was purchased, as they are continually polishing and varnishing it to preserve it.

One thing that needs attention is the matter of floors in the recreation rooms: They are cement, and were not properly finished off, and become very dusty. Aside from this, everything is in A-1 shape.

MACHINERY:

The boilers in the engine room are in good shape. The rest of the equipment is all run by electricity as the school is hooked up on the Calgary Power Company's electric transmission lines.
ST. MARY'S (Continued).—

TEACHING OF CHILDREN OTHER THAN CLASSROOM WORK:

The girls are taught general household work, including cooking, &c., and they also assist in making articles of clothing which are, for the most part, made at the school. The older boys, under the supervision of Brother Tom, do all the outside work.

Both the boys and girls, therefore, are taught the practical method of performing work that they are likely to have to do upon leaving school, and graduates of this school are well fitted for taking up their duties in household work and farming.

OUTBUILDINGS:

The outbuildings are all in splendid shape, as floors that were broken last summer when I was at the school have been repaired. A new outbuilding has also been erected by the Principal at a cost of about $500.00. There is a root cellar under the building and the building itself is for the purpose of storing grain. One end is partitioned off for a repair shop.

FARMING:

The school harvested a fair crop this year, and although the farm at the school was well operated, the yield just averaged about the same as the Indians' crop. The amount harvested was 2300 bushels of wheat, 1400 bushels of oats, 800 bushels of barley, 700 bushels of potatoes and a quantity of other garden truck. Eighty tons of green feed were put up and 160 acres of land were summerfallowed.

The school...
ST. MARY'S Continued,—

The school has 203 head of cattle and 27 head of horses, 35 pigs and 200 chickens. They were milking 16 cows which were giving about 10 pails of milk per day. This is all given to the children. Sixteen hundred (1600) pounds of butter were packed during the summer holidays which is also being used in feeding the children.

STAFF:

The staff consists of the Principal, Assistant Principal, one lay brother, one engineer, two labourers, one male teacher and fifteen sisters.

GENERAL:

In conclusion I wish to state that in my opinion this institution is well managed in every respect and the children are well fed and well clothed and receive the best of treatment.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.
Ottawa, December 9, 1932.

Sir:

I have your 402-11A., R.C., of the 2nd instant, reporting on your recent inspection of the Blood R. C. Indian Residential School. The Department is pleased to note that the work at this school is being conducted satisfactorily; that the health of the children is good and that the buildings are kept in a satisfactory condition. It is noted, also, that this institution was found to be well managed in every respect; that the children are well clothed and receiving good treatment.

In reply to your letter of the same date, regarding the condition of the cook stove, I have to say that our funds this year are extremely limited. If it is possible to carry on with the present stove, consideration will be given to authorizing the purchase of a new one next year. A request for this equipment might be forwarded the beginning of next fiscal year, when full particulars should be given as to the type of stove required and its approximate cost.

Your obedient servant,

I beg to acknowledge your letter of August 30th, 1932-5, with reference to the well at the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School, together with Encumbrance Requisition No. 906 for $400.00 to cover the cost of cleaning etc.

In this connection I wish to make my report on the matter.

The failure of the well and pump was in no way due to negligence, but to a collection of very coarse sand that had accumulated in the bottom of the well, of which there was about 15 feet, a sample of which I am mailing under separate cover. A certain amount of this sand would lift into the brass working barrel, and when this was removed by the well drilling rig, it was found that the brass barrel had worn to within 1/16 of an inch, and as a result it would not hold the leathers in the valve and would reverse them and render the pump useless. I, therefore, had to order a new working barrel with valves, and this has been put in and the pump is now working satisfactorily.

The supply of water to this well may of course be affected by the series of dry seasons, and there is not the continuous supply of water that existed four or five years ago, and if we have continuing dry seasons, it might be advisable to drop the pump down a further 40 feet into the well, and prevent the sucking of air which takes place when the pump is run for a long spell. I have advised that the pump be used more often and not so long in one run, and this will carry them along nicely. There is a great improvement since cleaning out the well and putting in the new barrel.

The cost of this work will be, approximately, as follows:

Well cleaning, including the lifting of the pump casing, rods etc., and putting the pump in shape, which included taking the pump out and making a temporary repair and putting in again that some water could be got to run on while cleaning the well and waiting for the brass barrel, which had to come from Winnipeg. The charge for bringing in the rig, 80 miles, and setting up etc., with labour on pump, is $150.00, Voucher No. 199, in favour of J. Maughan, 605 - 11th Street South, Lethbridge. The account for the brass barrel will be about $55.00 and express of $4.20, which accounts are not yet to hand. I spent a lot of time on the job myself in order to satisfy the Department that the job was done to satisfaction, and to see the conditions.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
While we were working on this well, the Principal of the St. Paul's Anglican School advised me that their pump had broken on September 1st, and the children in school. I went to the school to find that they were also out of water and found that the rods had broken off in the bottom of the well and the leather in the valves reversed and worn. I, therefore, deemed it advisable to pull this pump, and accordingly got the driller to set there at a cost of $75.00 to draw the pump and clean this well out, which was done. We found about six feet of a shale of a fine grade in this well, but the brass barrel in good shape. The rods were repaired by Weston Bros. of Cardston. That well is now working in good shape. I did find, however, that in this well, the pump sits fairly well up, is a 4" pipe pump, and the well casing is as shown in the log, reduced, and therefore the pump cannot be lowered. I would suggest that when next this well is worked on, that a 3" pump pipe be used and then lowered into the well casing.

As with the Blood School, I put in a lot of time at the Anglican School, and the cost of this work will be $75.00 for well rig and work, and a charge for repairs to rod and help in getting the rods out etc., to get a supply of water, pending the cleaning of the well.

Both schools rendered assistance in the work, particularly the Blood R.C. School, as the work is heavy, and the expense was kept down in this respect using only two on the well rig, and I may say that by careful planning, the two jobs have been done under the cost I estimated, and as a consequence of the break down at St. Paul's School, I did that job without wiring the Department for authority, as it appeared an absolute necessity to satisfy myself and the schools that an efficient water supply be maintained from all points of view. I trust the Department will concur in my actions in the matter.

The total cost of both jobs will not exceed $350.00, and the Department may be assured that the work was done economically, and that the water supply is sufficient at both schools.

Your obedient servant,

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 103-2-5 of the 17th instant authorizing the purchase of a range for the Blood R. C. School.

I have gone into this matter thoroughly and find that the most suitable range for the school would be the Gurney Oxford, three ovens, and this would cost $475 F. O. B. INSPECTOR'S OFFICE

PB CALGARY, ALTA... April 30th, 1934.

Dear Doctor McGill:

I have the honour to report on an inspection of St. Mary's Indian Residential School in the Blood Agency made on my recent visit to that reserve. While there I went over the entire building, inside and out, and was pleased to note that the school building itself is in an exceptionally good state of repair; practically as good as when they moved into it some 9 or 10 years ago. About all that is required at the present time is a little painting in the corridors and one or two rooms on the first floor. If the school were given about 25 gallons of paint and some oil, they would do the work themselves and I think this would be in the interest of economy as it will be put to good use.

The furniture in the school is also in splendid condition, and has certainly been well preserved by the Sisters. New linoleum had been

Doctor Harold W. McGill,
Deputy Superintendent General,
Department of Indian Affairs,
OTTAWA.
put in as floor-covering downstairs at a cost of approximately $250.00. This was paid for by the school management.

The outside buildings are all in pretty fair shape as far as it is possible for the staff to keep them, but owing to the very high winds there, considerable damage has been done to doors, shingles, &c., and they require a great deal of repairing to put them in proper shape. I would estimate that it would take a carpenter about a month to do the necessary work on these outbuildings, and if this is not soon done they will be in much worse condition later on. Once the shingles start to blow off and the wind gets in under them and the paper, it does not take long for a whole roof to be ruined. In my opinion it would be money well spent to attend to this matter right away. Very little material is required, and the expenditure would be principally for labour.

The bake oven needs replacing. It is badly burnt out and I am informed it was never of very much use as it was much too small. What is required is a 200-loaf bake oven.
The school is also experiencing difficulty with the water tower—It leaks like a sieve and whether it can be repaired sufficiently to be of use it is hard to say. It would have to be all re-corked with okum, and it is possible that while this is being done some new places might open up. I did not climb up into the tower to look over the tank; This is something that would require a younger man than I; and I would suggest that we get Mr. Weston of Cardston to see what really can be done to the tank. Some action will certainly have to be taken immediately as it is getting worse all the time.

FARMING:

As the Department are aware, this school operates a large farm, although the Principal informed me that he was not putting in as much wheat this year as last as he was sowing some of the farm land to green feed. Their farming operations were a failure last year on account of the drought, and they even had to purchase some potatoes during the winter. They raised a lot of garden truck.

They have about 200 head of cattle and hogs and a number of horses—all they require—and chickens, geese, turkeys, &c. All the beef and pork used by the school is produced there.
HEALTH:

The children appeared to be receiving the best of care and all looked very healthy. There were 153 in residence at the time of my visit and they all seemed very happy.

They get all the milk they can drink and as butter is made at the school they receive either fat or butter with their meals. The Department will realize that where a school raises a good garden, has some crop and raises all the beef and pork required, the children are naturally well fed. This is the case at this school and I was very well pleased with the appearance of the children.

TRAINING:

The boys do all the outside work under the able direction of Brother Thom, who is an excellent Farming Instructor.

The girls also receive a splendid training in the way of sewing, washing, cooking and other household duties, and if they do not make good use of the knowledge of housekeeping which they receive at school, it is not the fault of the Staff.

GENERAL:

When I left the school I said good-bye to Sister St. Patrick who informed me that she was leaving next
month for the East. Sister St. Patrick is about 65 years of age now and has spent about 35 years on the Blood and Peigan Reserves. She was Matron of our hospital on two different occasions and also has been Matron of the Blood School for a great number of years. It is with regret that I said good-bye to this Sister; she has rendered faithful service both at the school and in the hospital, and I have always found her work of the highest order. She has given the best part of her life in trying to make something of the Indian children under her care. I know she would appreciate very much a letter from the Department as she seemed to be quite sure that once she got down to the mother house she would be kept there owing to her age and that her labours in the field would be terminated.

The other members of the staff at the school seem to be rendering good service. There has been little change in the personnel since my last inspection.

Trusting the above report will be of interest to you,

I have the honour to be,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

M. Christianson

Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Alberta Inspectorate.
Sir:

I beg to refer you to my report on the St. Mary's Indian Residential School on the Blood Reserve, and would make the following recommendations which were all set out in my report:

1.- That the water tank which is leaking be repaired immediately, but not being sure whether or not it can be repaired satisfactorily, would suggest having Mr. Weston of Cardston, who has done a great deal of work for our Department, give us a report on this.

2.- That the Department hire a carpenter for a period of approximately a month to repair shingles, &c., on the barns and other outside buildings which have been damaged by the prevailing high winds.

3.- That the school be furnished with 25 gallons of paint and some linseed oil. This can be bought from one of the paint companies here wholesale, and shipped out to the school. This is required for the interior of the building, and the staff will do the work during their summer holidays.

4.- That when funds are available the school be furnished with a bake oven, size 200 loaves, as the old one has passed its usefulness.

Sir:

I beg to refer the Department to my letter #402-11A of June 29th, regarding Coping stones on the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, on the Blood reserve.

On July 11th, by Departments letter 103-25 an expenditure of $192.00 was authorized for the purpose of buying material and repairing the metal flashing on the roof. The material necessary was ordered from the Tresco Company of Edmonton, which amounted to $142.00, and was shipped to Cardston, and is now stored at the school.

I received a letter some time ago from Mr. Pugh advising me that in his opinion not sufficient had been allowed for labor, and that he would be glad if I would come down to the reserve for the purpose of looking into the matter of the roof and the coping stones. I went down there Monday and spent most of yesterday at the school. I got in touch with Mr. Weston who has done a lot of work for us on this reserve and who I know to be an Al workman and thoroughly competent in every respect, and Mr. Pugh the agent was also there, and the matter was thoroughly gone into and a means of repairing the Coping stones and flashings discussed.

To give the Department a better idea as to the state of the Coping stones than I could explain in this letter I am herewith attaching some snapshots of the building which shows where in some places the Coping stones are absolutely loose and can be lifted off. A considerable number of the corner stones have been lifted out on account of the fact that they were not safe, and a great deal of the facing has either been pulled or dropped off.

The Department will realize I am sure, that with the Coping stones loose it is very dangerous for the children playing around outside the school. The Department will also see that by the Coping stones being loose that water would get in under the coping stone and run down between the brick and the plaster, and a heavy rain, which we may sometime get, would play havoc with the building.

The metal flashing on the roof is very light material and only has a 1/8 turn on it, then pushed under the Coping stone and plastered here and there. It has pulled away from the wall in many places and rain and snow gets between the wall and the flashing and leaks through the roof. This would have to be repaired at the same time.

Sir:

I have your telegram of the 15th instant, regarding repairs required to the coping stones and flashing on the roofs at the Blood (St. Mary's) R.C. Indian Residential School. In this connection I regret that your No. 402-11A of the 12th ultimo was inadvertently overlooked.

With reference to the above mentioned repairs, I have to confirm night letter to you of today's date, as follows:

"May incur expenditure mentioned, your letter twelfth ultimo, repairing coping stones and flashing, roof, main building, chapel and laundry, St. Mary's School. Work may be performed by Ralph Weston. Writing."

The work in repairing the coping stones and metal flashing should be carried out in accordance with the suggested specifications forwarded in your letter above referred to. Either you or the local Agent should arrange for the purchase, from firms on the approved list, of the materials required, and Mr. Ralph Weston may be engaged to carry out the labour. Besides the repairs to the coping stones and flashing on the roof of the main building, the roof over the chapel and laundry should also be repaired and placed in good condition.

The Department notes that the cost of the repairs to the roof on the main building will be approximately $200 for labour and $40 for material, and for the repairs to the back part of the building, approximately $55 - a total of $295. It is noted, further, that there is an unexpended balance of approximately $60 from the last authority for repairs to this school. An encumbrance is being obtained, authorizing a further amount of $245.00 to complete the repairs mentioned. When the work is completed, you should forward accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the expenditure incurred. The work should be performed as soon as possible.

Sir:

I beg to advise that on a recent inspection for monthly report purposes at the Blood R.C. School, the first since their very bad epidemic of measles, that a number of troubles in the plant were brought to my attention, and I now wish to ask for authority to incur the following expenditures.

(1) Jacket Heater for Hot Water System. This has cracked, due to corrosion and sand in the system, and will have to be replaced. This was renewed three years ago, and is a trouble we have at both schools in the same manner; scaley water under heat and eventual corrosion then a splitting of the jacket. I believe that, in view of the fact that renewal of these cost about $130.00, it would be in the interests of economy to have some competent authority on water softeners give the Department a candid report as to their ability in the softening process to cut down the scaling of boiler heaters etc. An analysis could be made of the water at both schools to this end. I shall be glad of authority to make this replacement at the approximate cost mentioned.

(2) Water Front Gurney Oxford "G" Semi-Kitchen Range. This was found to be cracked and useless, and requires replacement at a cost of approximately, $20.00, the cost of the front being $16.00 and the installation around $5.00. In this case sand in the system was responsible, and as a result of my tracing this trouble, I have made arrangements to permit the children to go to their homes for four or five days, drain the water tower tank and thoroughly clean this out or sand, wherein I believe some of the trouble arises. I did not think it advisable to leave the children in school, with the water supply cut down to a minimum.

(3) Boilers, main. The fire door linings I found were burnt out and broken and will have to be replaced, otherwise the doors will begin to warp. I am not aware as yet of the cost of these. The weight of these is about 40 lbs. each and four of them will total 160 lbs. at an approximate cost of 30 to 35¢ per lb.

(4) Return and Steam Pipes to the Water Tower. In this case I called in the local plumber, as we found a leak in this piping, and on close examination a plug was found to be badly fitted and leaking and the drip pipes split, and it will be necessary to replace these to put this in good shape. As this was an emergency, I took the steps noted above. The cost will be kept as low as possible.

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Several of the features noted were to some extent due to the severe storm of last week, when 15° below zero weather came on overnight, at a time least expedited, and then it was found that by putting up the steam into the tower suddenly to prevent freezing that condensation set and freezing.

I should be glad if the Department will Nigh Letter their authority for these repairs before further cold weather sets in, and I trust that you concur in my involving certain necessary expenditure before obtaining authority.

Your obedient servant,

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I beg to state that I am advised, and note, by the Principal of the Blood R.C. School that the radiators in the water tower are all (four in number) frozen. Three of these have not been in use for some time, one only being in operation, which I think will carry sufficient heat for the tank. I would suggest, and I think it can be carried out, that all four radiators be taken down, and as they are in sections, we can find enough sections to build up one large radiator, which will suffice. This would entail labour only, with possibly some pipe, unions and nipples. I have discussed this with Mr. Inspector Christianson and he concurs in this suggestion. I have not obtained an estimate of this work, but it should not exceed $50.00 for labour and $20.00 for material. I would, therefore, respectfully seek authority to carry out this work.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir:

With reference to your 408-11 R.C. of the 27th ultimo, the Department regrets that the water towers at the St. Paul's C. E. and the Blood R. C. Indian Residential Schools were not painted during the last fiscal year. Funds were available for that purpose. However, it is noted from your letter that the material for both schools is now on hand and you may arrange for the necessary work. It is further noted that the cost of the labour will be $111.00 at each school.

There are certain funds available for repairs at each of these schools in our appropriation for the fiscal year 1936-37 and the Department will write you further about this matter next month. It should be understood, however, that the amount being authorized in this letter for painting the towers will have to be taken out of the amount provided for repairs and improvements in the current year's appropriation. Our funds are so limited that it will not be possible to consider allowing any amount over and above the appropriation.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 103-2-5, of June 16th last, with reference to the current year's appropriation for repairs and maintenance at the Blood Indian RC Residential School.

In reply I wish to state that I have consulted with the Rev. Father Devio, acting in the absence of the Principal, and the following repairs etc. are requested and recommended, under the heading of miscellaneous repairs.

Extension on kitchen chimney, ten feet. Cost $90.00
This is requested as the kitchen range installed last year has smoked badly with the prevailing West wind due no doubt to the flue in this range being 12" as against the old one of 8", and to install we had to open two chimney flues of 8" to accommodate the 12" flue. It will be necessary to take down the outside iron chimney stack to do this work, and rebuild the extension to the present stack. The cost is an estimated price inclusive of labor and material, given by Mr. Flett of Cardston.

Cupboards three in number. Cost $100.00
Two of these under the stair cases going down to the basement on each side of the building to the playrooms, boys and girls respectively. The Acting Principal requests these to accommodate brooms, etc., and also states that they find these spaces under the stairs used in an objectionable way by the children, and two cupboards placed in these positions would prevent this and serve a useful purpose.

The other cupboard is asked for in the boys' playroom to put in clothing that they work in etc., and similar to one installed in the girls' playroom. The cost is an estimate provided by Mr. Weston of Cardston, and is inclusive of labor and material.

Painting of outside front porch. Cost $31.10.

Fencing playground. The amount allowed will provide two sides on the road allowances with woven wire fence, which has been purchased. Some posts and perhaps two by four lumber may be required, not to exceed the amount allowed of $200.00.

Sir:

I have the honor to submit herewith my report for the month of August.

SCHOOLS

Both schools were visited during the month, largely for repair jobs to be looked into. No children being in school this month. At the St Paul's Anglican School, paint was provided for the school and the labor of painting being done by the staff. Brick work pointing was done on all the windows, doors and coping stones on the roof. Roof painting was not carried out, the matter being placed before the Department regarding the labor entailed in the work. At the Blood R.C. school, their repairs were looked over and the matter referred to the department, and the work necessary and authorized is now being proceeded with. Crops at both schools was very poor, averaging about 4 bushels to the acre. The potato crops were also useless and they will be faced with purchases in both flour and potatoes.

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith Vouchers Nos. 861 and 862, amounting to $343.18, in favour of R. Weston of Cardston, Alta.

These vouchers cover the painting of the water towers at the St. Mary's R.C., and St. Paul's Anglican Indian Residential Schools, Blood Agency.

Considerable difficulty has been experienced in this work, and the explanation covering this transaction is as follows:

The tender on this work was submitted by Mr. Hingly of Calgary in 1935, and work was commenced in November of that year, but not concluded on account of bad weather, particularly winds, and the work was delayed till this Spring. Mr. Hingly then delegated Mr. R. Weston to conclude this work, and in doing so it entailed labour costs over the estimate, and at the St. Paul's School, it entailed extra material.

The matter was referred to the Department on March 27th last, letter No. 402-11R.C., and a reply was received, No. 103-1-5 of April 2nd last. The original material, which Tremco supplied through Mr. Hingly, was paid for in Voucher No. 272, of October 11th, 1935, leaving an amount of $222.00 for labour for both towers. The estimate in labour was insufficient and this has been exceeded by $69.75, while the material extra required amounted to $51.43, a total in excess of the amount estimated of $121.18. Mr. Weston has endeavoured to have Mr. Hingly absorb some of this, without avail, and in discussing the matter with Mr. Weston, who as stated concluded this work for Mr. Hingly of Calgary, I find that Mr. Weston is out of pocket in many respects on the work, it being extremely difficult work, and occupied four men for the most part, the use of scaffolding and block and tackle gear to ensure safety. Workmen's compensation fees also having to be paid. The cheque for tower paint in Voucher No. 272, of October 11th, 1935, was $101.00.

I regret that this circumstance arose, and every effort was made by myself to offset this additional charge arising. Mr. Hingly has now left the Tremco Manufacturing Co. employ, and it seems impossible to hold him to his tender on this work. I would respectfully ask the Department to give consideration to Mr. Weston's account, who completed the work for Mr. Hingly, and to whom the vouchers should be paid.

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg to submit herewith Voucher No. 929, amounting to $75.80, in favour of Mr. F.W. Flett, Plumber of Cardston. In this connection I wish to state that the account represents the repairing of the steam pipe line leading to the water tower at the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School.

It was found after completion of the radiator work in the tank tower, that the steam line was split in the piping for over 15 feet and had to be renewed, as it was impossible to raise any steam to the tower. As this line is an encased line, it was an expensive repair job, but one of necessity, and with the expectancy of cold weather, I instructed Mr. Flett to make the necessary repair. The cause is not known of this splitting of the pipe line, and being a covered pipe cannot be discerned until steam is raised to the tank line, consequently it had not been noticed during the Summer, since shutting off the plant last Spring. A leak was noticed last Winter, but not to interfere at that time, I regret not obtaining authority, but lateness of the season compelled me to have the work done to prevent further damage, and trust the Department will concur.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 103-2-5, of the 30th December, 1937, with reference to the sale of a small high pressure boiler for the sum of $20.00. In reply I wish to state that the boiler sold was the one which it was intended to trade, but as stated in my letter of the 5th of November last, File No. 402-11 R.C., the Alberta Temple found that it was not suited for their purpose, and had made other arrangements, we had the boiler left on our hands. President E.J. Wood, however, took steps to assist me in disposing of the boiler in question, and it was sold to B.J. Wood of Cardston.

The reason of sale was that it was too small for the school purpose, and its condition was fair. It was stripped of all fittings which were used on the boiler from the Alberta Temple, except for the injector. The Hutterite Colony offered us the same money in a casual offer, but later thought it not worth the money, so that when Mr. Wood made the offer of $20.00 I accepted. I asked $25.00, but this was refused. I am attaching separate sheet for your convenience for the Salvage Department, and I regret that I did not take more precaution, knowing full well the channel through which such sales must go, but in view of the manner of this transaction, I thought that my procedure would be in order, especially so, after referring the matter to the Branch and receiving no contrary instructions.

Dear sir,

I beg to refer to your serious consideration the fact that in this St Mary's School no safe exit have been provided for the small children's dormitories located on the second floor of this building. In these two dormitories some thirty-five small children ranging from seven to ten years of age have their sleeping quarters. It is impossible for them to reach the fire escape provided for the top dormitories, and in case of fire their only way of escape would be to run down the flight of stairs through the smoke and then go to the centre door; this is more than could be asked of small children in case of fire.

Therefore, I shall be very much obliged if you will kindly submit the matter to the Department of Indian Affairs as soon as possible.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your report for the month of January regarding the Blood Residential School and have particularly noted the following statement in the letter of the Principal:

"I beg to refer to your serious consideration the fact that in this St. Mary's School no safe exit have been provided for the small children's dormitories located on the second floor of this building. In these two dormitories some thirty five small children ranging from seven to ten years of age have their sleeping quarters.

"It is impossible for them to reach the fire escape provided for the top dormitories, and in case of fire their only way of escape would be to run down the flight of stairs through the smoke and then go to the centre door; this is more than could be asked of small children in case of fire."

I have carefully reviewed our file for the past few years and can find no previous mention of the necessity for the fire escape which Father Levern now mentions. In official letter of July 24, 1937 you were advised regarding the amount available for repairs and improvements at the Blood School and you replied in a letter dated August but made no mention of the fire escapes. In view of this the Department is at a loss to understand why this matter has been overlooked if it is as urgent as the letter of the Principal would indicate.

J. E. Pugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cardston, Alta.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your file No. 103-2-5 of the 9th instant, with reference to the matter of fire escapes, Blood Indian R.C. School.

In reply I wish to state that this matter came up when I made my monthly inspection of this school, and as is my custom, I ask if fire drill is being kept up, and the Rev. Father Levern and Assistant Principal, Rev. Father Charbon, mentioned this subject matter, and I requested their statement in writing.

This, I may say, was the first time that the matter of the safety of the children on the second floor was brought to my attention, and was not mentioned last August, when dealing with the repairs etc. under estimates provision.

I interviewed the Fathers on the 15th, I also visited the school, the Fathers being absent on the reserve, and on the latter date I checked over the fire escape provision made, and I am enclosing rough sketches showing the lay out of escapes, and the outside connections to windows and doors of the building respectively for the three floors. From this it will be noted that the top floor exit is by doors, 2nd floor by windows. This latter is the one point of issue, and it is noted that the exit here is by windows on both ends of the building. The windows are the customary sash window, sliding upwards for a half sash length, and I note that outside there are storm windows on, with hook catches on the inside. In front of the window (as per the attached rough sketch, No. 1 & 2) is a radiator and the distance from floor to window ledge is 33½", and this could be improved upon with some expense, by replacing the window with a hinged door of the full length of window opening so that the passage out to the fire escape (which has a landing at both points) could be made without crawling through the bottom half of the window. This would apply to both sides of the building. I would also suggest that steps be provided in front of the radiator to overcome the 33½" from floor to window sill. I measured the distance from the doors of both dormitories across the corridor, and on the north, this distance is only 50 feet; on the south 50 feet, across a corridor and past the stair cases that lead up and down to the other floors, and if the provision made as outlined above are made, the exits in my opinion would be very good. Estimates are given for these changes.

The escapes themselves are good, and are as follows:- The escapes on the south end of the building goes from top floor to ground floor, with extension to ground.

R.A. HOEY, ESQ.,

Dear Mr. Pugh:

The following letter has just been received from the Principal of the Blood Residential School:

"I beg to thank you for your circular letter of the 10th inst., No. 150-65, and to tell you that we will do our best to follow your good advice. Now, in that circular, you say that any Principal who is not satisfied with the fire escape and fire prevention facilities should report to the Department; this gives me a good occasion to let you know that there is not one fire extinguisher nor any fire axe in this school house. It was one of the first things that I remarked when I was appointed to take charge of this school, and I am still wondering what may be the reason for it."

I am at a loss to understand the above letter in view of the fact that I was under the impression that at all our Residential Schools there were fire extinguishers and some other fire prevention equipment.

I would appreciate your comments on the letter at the earliest possible date and, if conditions are as stated by the Principal, you might let me know the number of fire extinguishers and other equipment which you consider should be supplied.

Yours truly,

R. A. Hays,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
