Sir:

I beg to state that I have just been called to the Blood R.C. School of this Agency to find that the high pressure boiler there has sprung about 12 tubes in the top crown plate, while one tube has split.

On looking over this job, I am of the opinion that it will be necessary to renew all the tubes, and with this in view I have obtained the cost of this repair job from the only boiler people in Lethbridge or vicinity, the Lethbridge Iron Works, and the following is quoted by this firm:

50 tubes, measuring 3' 4½" long, a total of approximately 170 feet of 2" tube at $0.75 per foot, $127.50, and labour costs at Lethbridge, 50 flues @ 1.50 per flue, $75.00, with an inspection fee of $5.00, a total of $207.50.

This boiler does about three days a week washing, and our water is bad for corrosion, and at inspection last Fall, under 300# water pressure, no sign of leak disclosed itself. It is thought that the action of the water is responsible for corrosion and its effect on the tubes in the upper crown plate.

Could authority be granted by wire in order that we may facilitate the school work and cause no undue delay in their weekly washing, as I can have this work done in between washings. The school authorities agree to deliver the boiler to Lethbridge and return without cost, on their own truck.

Dear Sir:

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge your file No. 103-2-5, of the 16th instant, with reference to Voucher No. 645, for boiler inspection services.

In reply I wish to state that this service covered the inspection of the high pressure boiler received for use at the Blood R.C. School.

The regulations call for inspection of new-fired boilers before use, and as the work was done in Lethbridge, at the Iron Works, it became a special inspection under Section 17 of the Boiler Act, 1929, Chapter 73.

The rate of wages is as stated $14.00 per diem, with mileage at eight cents per mile.

Authority was given in telegram dated May 10th, 1938, and inspection followed, hence the special charge. Fee will not be charged on this boiler again this year. It is, therefore, recommended that payment be made of this voucher.

Re: Purchase of dough-mixer for St. Mary's Indian Residential School (R.C.), Blood Agency:

Sir:

I have the honour to enclose herewith copy of letter received from Mr. J. E. Pugh, Indian Agent, Cardston, which is self-explanatory.

Upon receipt of same I made enquiries from the Butchers and Packers Supplies, Ltd., Calgary, reprices on a one-bag (100 pounds) -size machine: On July 24 I received their reply which reads, in part:

"In response to your enquiry for prices on Dough Mixers we are pleased to quote:

'Fig. 2898 - one bag Super Dough Mixer,
with our new model patented Mixing Arm
and bowl cleats and with 60 cycle, 3
phase Motor, direct connected: $410.00,
60 cycles, single phase motor, direct
connected: $420.00,

These one bag Super Mixers are quoted ex-
clusive of cover. Should a cover be required
there would be an extra charge of $30.00, for
a plain canopy cover.'"

Enclosed with the letter was a photograph of the machine. I am forwarding same herewith. On the back of this will be found a description of same.

On August 3rd I wrote the principal asking him to come to Calgary at as early a date as possible to discuss the matter with me, and if possible view the machine: He called on me this A.M. and whilst he did not see the machine, as the company do not stock same here, Rev. Charron says he is satisfied it will meet his requirements, and he is most anxious that same be supplied, as he claims he cannot do without same any longer.

I strongly recommend that this machine be supplied and that the order be placed by the Department direct, as by doing so I am of the opinion that they can get a discount. Shipment is to be made to Cardston, Alta.

The motor required is a SINGLE PHASE. The School is on the Calgary Power Line.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. of Mines & Resources,
OTTAWA.

EX'D.

On August 28, last, a requisition was sent forward from this Branch to the Purchasing Division, asking for the purchase of a dough mixer, at an estimated cost of $420.00, for use at the Blood R. C. Indian Residential School.

I am this morning in receipt of a protest from the office of the Minister in respect to the purchase of this equipment. The officials are anxious to know if this dough mixer is being purchased to replace one already in use or if a dough mixer is being installed for the first time. In view of the war conditions now confronting us, we are carefully reviewing all such purchases, in the hope that by careful scrutiny we can reduce expenditures. The purchase of equipment such as this for residential schools has been brought up and reviewed by this Branch from time to time during the last two or three years. I am personally of the opinion that pupils in attendance at our residential schools should be encouraged, not only to bake bread, but to do a great deal of useful work, the accomplishment of which will train them for life on the reserves. It is just possible, however, that the mixing of dough for an institution as large as the Blood R. C. school might take up more of the students' time than could easily be spared from other duties.

I should like you to go into this matter very fully with the Principal and let us have a comprehensive report on the matter. This report should serve as a guide not only in respect to this particular purchase but in respect to similar purchases at other residential schools. I feel confident the officials at the office of the Minister will be guided largely by your recommendation.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

J. E. Pugh, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Cardston, Alberta.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter No. 103-2-5 of the 27th ultimo, with reference to the purchase of a dough mixer at an approximate cost of $420.00 for the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School.

In reply I wish to state that I have gone into this matter at this school and find the following conditions exist:

Quantity of loaves baked per diem, 120 to 135
flour used approximately 175 lbs.
Labour used to do the mixing, a baker paid by the school authorities.
Size of bake room, 10 feet wide by 22 feet long.
oven in the above room, 7 x 7, with three feet clearance back wall, 18" on side wall.
Bread racks occupy one wall for steaming out, and then stored in cellar under school building, which is a damp location.

The bake room could not be used for hand mixing of dough by girls, aged 14 to 16 years, being small and baking temperature of 200° in room. Sisters have been used and also big boys and was found harmful to both.

Provision for teaching girls baking in all aspects is made classes being held in kitchen proper to teach baking in family size.

The Principal informs me that at the LeBret School, similar conditions for teaching girls baking are provided there. School staff and children number approximately 167 persons.

The dough mixer will be a new acquisition to this school. All dough mixing being done by hand previously.

Principal would be satisfied with mixer of approximately 100 to 150 lb. flour size.

If mixer not provided, conditions for this work being carried out by girls would necessarily have to be improved by alterations to bakery room, and space does not readily permit of this.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.
In view of the fact that this school does carry out the desires of the Department, that the girls learn home cooking, and that the school population is large, requiring amounts of breed quoted, it is recommended that a mixer of the size suggested be provided.

Monthly inspection reports on girls' classes of bakery can provide check on the Department's desires being carried out, and insistence upon such classes being one of the subjects reported upon.

Your obedient servant,

J.H. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

I beg to make the following report on the water situation both the Blood R.C. School and the St Paul's Residential School, which necessitated the sending of a Night Lettergram dated December 29th 1940 as follows:

"Blood School deep well blocked by sand, no water, St Paul's School pumping sand with water, Recommend Rig clean both wells, Approximate cost cleaning both wells and emergency repairs, three hundred and fifty dollars. Will keep cost at minimum, Urgent."

On Saturday December 28th I was called to the R.C. School by Father Charron regarding no water, at the School and found the pump functioning but a very small flow of water at the start when pumping and after a few minutes it completely stopped, as new leathers had been put on the upper cylinder, it was certain that the trouble was the rise of sand in the well, or a breakage in the lower barrel, this could not be ascertained without the lifting of the pump and the pulling of the piping and cylinders. I went to Lethbridge and interviewed Joe Maughan Well Driller, and the price of $100.00 per well was made, to cover both Schools, the balance of amount quoted is to cover the possibility of the Lower Brass Barrels at both places, being replaced. There is also the prospect of the pump piping in place, have to be repaired or replaced.

The price of $100.00 per school covers the lifting of the pump casing rods etc., the cleaning of the well, and replacing of the pump and casing.

I would draw your attention to the letter of the 18th September 1935 from Mr Puch which covers the technical points of the trouble which seems to have recurred again after 6 years of use.

I will make every effort to keep the expense as low as possible, and will advise the Department immediately the work has been done as to the ultimate findings, as regards a normal flow of water for both schools in the future.

Sir:

I beg to advise further to my Air Mail letter File 402-11R.C. of the 29th of December, that after pulling the pump and cleaning out 18 feet of sand and going to the bottom of the originally drilled well the following situation has arisen.

After replacing the brass bearing and checking all other parts, and setting up the pump, it was found that there was practically no water. The flow being 3 gallons of water in 4 minutes, as this will hardly supply the staff requirements, I advised Father Charron to advise the parents to keep the children at home until a normal supply of water is procured.

By today (Sunday) the upper floors of the School are without water, also the tank is now down to a depth of two feet of water, and the water supply diminishing rapidly.

Mr J Maughan is returning Monday and intends to extend the pump cylinder down 60 feet to see if we can strike the flow at that level, the bottom of the cylinder piping is now at a level of 106 feet, and the extension of 60 feet will bring the working barrel to 166 feet, if this does not bring a sufficient supply Mr Maughan is agreeable to try and lower the well a few feet to try and bring the stream back to normal. The success of this is doubtful and consequently I would greatly appreciate the Departments suggestion and advice to further action on this well. It will be a considerable expense to drill deeper in this well, and with this in mind may I be allowed to suggest that the advice of a member of the Waters Branch as the reason for the sudden stoppage before any further expense is assumed. The water supply of this well although pumping sand with the water has given a fair supply of water up till the sudden stoppage.

I would like to state that there is no fear of the heating system, being cut off as this water is supplied from a soft water cistern, which I am informed will take the heating through till Spring.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

With reference to your inquiry about the water supply for the Indian school on the Blood Indian Reserve located on section 18, Township 4, Range 25, west of 4th Meridian, I looked up the geological condition and the information we had from the nearest wells.

The school is located in an area underlain by the Willow Creek formation. This formation is usually very shaly with few beds of fine-grained sand. Judging from the fact that the reports show that coarse sand came into the well when it was cleaned I am inclined to believe that the water supply occurs in the formation below the Willow Creek on the St. Mary's formation. If this is the case there is a good chance that other water-bearing sands occur below the sand in which the present supply is obtained. To reach new sands it would be necessary to drill possibly a hundred feet deeper.

The chances are that the stoppage of the present supply is due to cavings of soft clay shale into the empty space left by the sand which has been withdrawn by pumping during the life of the well. If this is true it would be possible to obtain an adequate supply by drilling in a new location to the same horizon as that of the present well.
If the present well is deepened or a new well drilled the water-bearing sand should be properly screened to prevent the sand from flowing into the well. A metal screen will probably do although a gravel screen would give the best results.

If you should deepen the well or drill a new well you should have the driller keep samples of the rock he passes through in drilling. If there is any question about deeper drilling we will be better able to advise you as to what should be done if we have samples of the rock to identify the formation.

Yours sincerely,

R.T.D. Wickenden,
Officer in Charge,
Water Supply & Boring Section,
Geological Survey.
Sir:

Report St Mary's R.C. School well at Blood Agency.

Reference Mr A McMillan, clerk in charge, letter No 403-11 R.C., dated December 29th, and January 5th, I beg to report that this P.M. I have called at the School with Mr McMillan, and interviewed Mr J.P. Maughan of Lethbridge Alta, also Mr V C Sill of Macleod Alta, who states he operated the machine when this well was sunk in May 1924.

The following is a brief history of the well, 5 5/8 inch inserted joint steel casing was used, No written Log of the formation traversed was kept. From memory Mr Sill says "the first hundred feet was clay and boulders, the next 90 feet was sandy clay formation; After the first 100 feet the casing had to be put in as drilling proceeded, because the formation would not hold (stand up). The casing drove in very tough the deeper we went the tougher it got to put it down, and we had to bind it in. The last 8 or 9 feet was pure sandstone with 1 or 2 feet of coarse sand & gravel. Water rose to within 20 feet of the surface. No screen was put in the bottom of the well.

106 Feet of pump pipe was put in with a 30" X 31 working barrel or pump cylinder, at the bottom, this worked nicely the water supply was plentiful."

The School staff say that the pump always brought up sand.

In September 1933 the well was cleaned, some 12 to 15 feet of sand was taken out of it, at the lower part of the casing, a new working barrel or cylinder was put in, the old one being worn out by pumping sand; See Agent Pugh's letter of September 18th 1933, the water again coming up to 22 feet from its surface.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept of Mines & Resources
Ottawa.
Rev Father Charron who has been in charge since May 1937, states that the pump has been lifting sand continuously, and states that he has had to replace the leathers quite often, several times a year. About three weeks ago he noticed the water supply diminishing, he again changed the leathers but got no results, a few days later the flow was only about 1 gallon per minute for a few minutes, at a time.

On Thursday January 2nd 1941 Mr J P Maughan brought his outfit to the pump and cleaned the some 18 feet of sand out of the casing, he checked the working barrel carefully, put it back in but got no better results, about 3 gallons in four minutes.

On January 6th he again cleaned out about 4 feet of sand which had again accumulated in the bottom of the casing. There was no improvement in the flow of water, again the pump was taken out and some 22 feet of sand and mud had come up in the casing. He is now unable to stop sand and mud from coming up, and the water supply is not improving.

In conversation Mr Maughan stated that he thought that by lowering a five inch casing inside the present six inch one, and drilling the well deeper, that there was a chance of cutting the mud and sand that was heavy, and get a good flow of water in the lime strata or shale. Of course he cannot guarantee that this will be successful. If this is not successful we shall have chance of salvaging the casing (5") If successful it will mean the purchase of new pump and piping of a smaller size.

My recommendation is that the Dominion Water Power Bureau be asked to take care of the work.

I wish to bring to your attention an emergency which demands immediate action on the part of the Department of Indian Affairs.

On the Blood Indian Reserve, in the southern part of this province, St. Mary's R. C. Indian Reserve School, Cardston, has been without a water supply since January 4th last. Although three reports and two night letters have been forwarded to Ottawa through the local Indian Agent and the Inspector of Indian Affairs, no response has been forthcoming.

The condition has wrought great hardship in the institution. Finding it impossible to convey water from the town of Cardston fifteen miles across a winter prairie, 145 children have been sent to their homes, many of them to homes in which conditions of starvation exist. I regret that I have to bother you with this matter, but the situation is far more serious than may appear to the Department. May I respectfully ask you to have it investigated immediately so that the excellent work, which the Indian Department has conducted through this school, may be resumed without further delay.

Yours sincerely,

My dear Bishop Carroll:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of January 21, in which you intimate that the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, on the Blood Reserve, has been without an adequate water supply since January 4, last.

The records here indicate that the condition of the well at the St. Mary's School was first brought to the attention of the Department in a telegram from the clerk of the agency, dated December 30, 1940. In this telegram the clerk stated that the well was blocked by sand and would require cleaning and emergency repairs. The clerk was authorized, by telegram, dated December 30, to proceed with the repairs that he might find necessary.

In a telegram dated January 21, 1941, the clerk reported: "Operations at well unsuccessful; no water; awaiting instructions".

Immediately following receipt of this letter, the desirability of providing an adequate water supply at the Blood School was discussed by the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch with the officer in charge of the Water Supply and Boring Section of the Geological Survey Division of this Department. After the matter had been thoroughly discussed and an expression of opinion secured from the Well Boring Division, a telegram dated January 17, 1941, was sent to Inspector Schmidt, asking him to proceed with the construction of a new well at

AIR MAIL

Ottawa, January 27, 1941.

Dear Sir:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of January 21, in which you intimate that the purchase and installation of a new electric motor for pumping water at the St. Mary's School, on the Blood Reserve, is a matter that requires technical or expert advice, and that an official of the Dominion Water Power Bureau, in your judgment, should be called upon to take charge of the work.

It was very disturbing to me and the officials here to learn from your letter of January 21 that the work of constructing a well at the St. Mary's School had not been undertaken at that date. It was our opinion that the instructions issued to you in official telegram of January 17 were very definite and explicit. The matter was further discussed in an air mail letter addressed to you, also on January 17.

It is difficult to understand why you did not issue instructions to the Principal to proceed immediately with the actual work of construction. The information with respect to the best type of pump and the selection of a proper screen are matters that surely could have been taken up with the experts or with the Department, later.

It is my understanding that Mr. Fetterly's office is in the Federal Building at Calgary. In view of this fact, I am anxious to know why you did not find it convenient to consult him with respect to the pump and the screens and in this way secure his advice and guidance. It is noted that in your letter of January 21 you suggest that a sample of the mud, sand or silt be sent to the manufacturer of the screen to determine the size required. This appears to me to be a reasonable suggestion and one that might be acted upon by an inspector on his own initiative.

I am sending forward, for your information, a summary of the steps that have been taken to supply water at the Blood School. When you have read this summary you will feel convinced, as I have become convinced, that this is a striking illustration of how public business should not be conducted, and certainly an illustration of how public business should not be conducted in a period as critical -

Mr. C. P. Schmidt,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Calgary, Alberta.

My dear Bishop Carroll:

I have for acknowledgment Your Lordship's letter of January 27, in which you intimated that the St. Mary's Indian Residential School, on the Blood Reserve, has been without an adequate water supply since January 4, last.

The records here indicate that the condition of the well at the St. Mary's School was first brought to the attention of the Department in a telegram from the clerk of the agency, dated December 30, 1940. In this telegram the clerk stated that the well was blocked by sand and would require cleaning and emergency repairs. The clerk was authorized, by telegram, dated December 30, to proceed with the repairs that he might find necessary.

In a telegram dated January 21, 1941, the clerk reported: "Operations at well unsuccessful; no water; awaiting instructions".

Immediately following receipt of this letter, the desirability of providing an adequate water supply at the Blood School was discussed by the officials of the Indian Affairs Branch with the officer in charge of the Water Supply and Boring Section of the Geological Survey Division of this Department. After the matter had been thoroughly discussed and an expression of opinion secured from the Well Boring Division, a telegram dated January 17, 1941, was sent to Inspector Schmidt, asking him to proceed with the construction of a new well at

the Blood School. It is just possible, however, that Inspector Schmidt was ill and confined to bed at this date and consequently not in a position to carry out the instructions sent forward to him. His clerk, in a radiogram dated Calgary, January 21, states:

"Mr. Schmidt in bed with Grippe. He asks that some other official of Dominion Water Power Bureau and the Principal of the School be put in charge of constructing new well at Blood School."

Inspector Schmidt's clerk was instructed in a telegram dated January 24, to communicate with Reverend Father Charron, Principal of the School, and authorize him to proceed immediately with the construction of a well.

I must express regret at the delay that has occurred in the construction of this well. In view of all the circumstances, however, I cannot see how this delay could have been avoided. It is altogether likely that by this date the well is at least partly constructed and it is my hope that an adequate supply of water will be available at the institution, immediately following the completion of the work now in progress.

Sir;-

Re Blood R C School Well

I beg to advise that on the 27th inst. I received a call by telephone from Mr. J.P. Schmidt Inspector of Indian Agencies Calgary, advising me that he had returned to the Office, after being under the Doctor's care for a week, asking me to come to Calgary along with Father Charron of the Blood School Cardston, and Mr. Joe Maughan well Driller Lethbridge. I left the Agency along with the above parties and arrived at the Calgary Office at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 28th January. During the 28th and 29th of January we went into all the details regarding the drilling of a new well, and the following are the prices received regarding the drilling of the new well which is now in progress, with a detail of work considered to complete the project.

DRILLING OF WELL

As mentioned in previous correspondence the price quoted by Mr. Joe Maughan for drilling of $1.50 per foot was agreed to. The casing caused considerable time to decide on as the 6-7/8 casing previously mentioned in recent letters was not procurable, and the price of this casing if it had been possible to get it had increased to about $2.00 per foot owing to war price increase. After considerable time had been spent 6" Line Casing was located at the price of $1.82 per foot F.O.B. Calgary, the moving of this piping from Calgary to Macleod was taken care of by the firm supplying the casing, and will be included on their account when received; it was also found necessary to have a shoe made to force the casing down the well, and 2 extra collars to connect short lengths of pipe needed when the well is at the lower levels. The shoe costs $20.00, and the extra collars $1.75 each, and will all be included in the Account from Wilkinson & McLean of Calgary who received the contract.

The question of a Gravel Screen was taken up, and it was found that this would have to be made by A.G. Cooke of Lawrenceburg Indiana U.S.A., Mr. Maughan wrote to him at the Calgary Office advising him to be prepared to make the necessary screen when samples from the bottom of the well had been taken out and shipped to him by express from Coutts, so as to save any delay, the cost of this screen is unknown at present until the screen has been made; Mr. Maughan has undertaken to have this come to him and he will release same from the Customs, and the cost of the screen will appear on his account when sent in.

Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept Mines & Resources
Ottawa
DRILLING OF WELL (contd)

There will also be a charge of approximately $50.00 by Mr. Vaughan for the placing of the screen in the bottom of the well when completed, owing to the necessity of raising the casing to sink the screen in place. Attention has been paid to the Department's request for samples and sacks have been obtained and samples have been kept of the soil formation in the well and will be forwarded to Ottawa as requested. The purchase of a Working Barrel cylinder will be reported on under Cost of changing water pipe connections.

CONSTRUCTION OF PIT.

If drilling is successful and water in sufficient quantities is available, there will then be the digging of the pit and the enclosing of the pit with concrete walls, this pit will connect with the present Boiler Room of the School. This will cause the digging out of a pit 12' X 12' or 12' X 9' where the well is drilled, the cutting of a doorway from the Boiler Room to the pit through a 16" concrete wall, enclosing of the pit with concrete walls, laying of a concrete floor, and the building of a reinforced concrete roof with a manhole in centre to allow of the pulling of the pump when necessary. The manhole to be covered with a zinc top to stop any leakage into pit. Gravel for this work has to be hauled a distance of 25 miles. This estimate from a local contractor R. Weston, Cardston, is complete for this work and amounts to the sum of $300.00, with an addition of $10.00 if the pit is extended from 12'x9' to 12'x12'.

CONNECTING PIPES.

This item covers the cutting of pipes and connecting pump to the main water line which runs to the water tower, the installation of all valves and check valves and laying of drain pipe to run any overflow to the nearest trap. $50.00 of this estimate covers the purchase and attaching a new Working Barrel Cylinder to the pump, and is done on the advice of Mr. Fetterly of the Dominion Water Branch, and Mr. Vaughan who recommend against the putting in of the old Working Barrel, into a new well. The present working barrel has been in the well since 1932 and may at any time perforate as the brass is badly worn. This article has also to be purchased in the United States, but will be taken care of by the local plumber at the price quoted. I might state that in previous correspondence the price of $50.00 was quoted but this price was taken from the cost of a working barrel purchased in 1932, this work has been placed in the hands of Mr. Flett of Cardston at the quotation of $185.00.

MOTOR ATTACHMENTS & MOTOR.

Prices on this work were taken on both the Single Phase and the three phase system of lighting connections. As the prices received showed the single phase motor quoted at almost double the price of the Three phase motor, and the single phase motor very difficult to procure, it was decided to do any purchasing on the basis of the Three Phase. This involved the changing of the single phase now in use from the Calgary Power Co to a three phase system, however when visiting the Calgary Power Co in regard to the change, we were advise that this change would not cost the Department any expense the Power Co making the necessary change, and adding a monthly service charge extra to the Blood School of $2.00 per month which was agreed to by Father Charron. As will be seen by the quotations enclosed, the prices received from the Canadian Firms.
Motor & Motor attachments.

Canadian Firms, Canadian Westinghouse & General Electric, were the same, and as the Wilkinson & McClean quoted on a motor the name of which was not mentioned, although slightly less we understood repairs would be hard to get for it, it was decided to pace this work with Cardston Motors who were the only party to make a bid for the installation, and who would use the Canadian Westinghouse Motor. This bid amounts to the sum of $1627.44 covering the purchase of Motor, switches, and installation.

Belting.

The purchase of a pulley and belting V Type I have been advised will be approximately $75.00, however the Cardston Motors are making enquiries as to whether the pulley wanted is available, and will inform me as soon as possible. If this letter has not been mailed by the time I receive, I will quote the exact price when received. This will be installed by the Cardston Motors of Cardston.

February 7th 1941

Sir:

I beg to make the following report on the above well, which has been drilling during the past week and has now struck a good flow of water.

In co-operation with Father Charron I have kept in touch with this well during the past week, and having been advised by the Father that he has been in telegraphic communication with the Officials of our Department regularly, I have not communicated with the Dept since the well was started to see overlapping.

After striking a small flow of water just below the 200 foot level, the well was drilled further and the dept of 206 feet a good flow of water was secured, at 2:30 P.M. on Wednesday the fifth inst a 24 hour test of the well was started, and after running at the rate of 15 gallons per minute, for 6 or 7 hours, it was decided to make connections with the water tower as the water was running fairly clear and the well was shut down for a few minutes, during this time the fine sand which had been pumped with the water settled in the top of the working barrel, the pump was pulled and it was found that two of the pump rods had been broken in trying to work the working barrel. However when the well was checked we found that only a foot of sand was in the bottom of the well, so samples of the sand formation were immediately taken, and Father Charron air mailed them from Browning Montana so as to expedite the return of the screen from Indiana. I went to Lethbridge to arrange for the immediate release of same when the screen arrived in Lethbridge, we are satisfied that the flow of water is the best they have had at the school, and hope that with the screen installed that this will give a very satisfactory well. It is our intention when when completing the well to put the pump tubing and piping to the bottom of the well, so as to keep the Screen from filling up with sand. No extra work as the digging of the pit and the installing of the motors will be done until the screen has been installed and the well tested on 24 hour run.

I will advise further when the screen has been put in place and the test made.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I have for acknowledgment your No. 103-2-5 of the 28th ultimo, re the Blood R.C. School well. I must first ask to be excused for not having replied sooner; I beg to say that the reason for this was that I was confined to my home, and for the greater part of the time to my bed, being quite sick. I returned to the office on the 13th instant, feeling better, but still somewhat weak and subject to head-aches.

I can appreciate your feeling disturbed when receiving letters from outsiders which led you to think that there was unnecessary delay in starting drilling on the new well; taking everything into consideration from this end, however, I do not think there was any undue delay.

I was sick in bed when the contents of your letter of the 17th ultimo, received at this office on the 20th, were made known to me. — May I be allowed to remark that I was in doubt as to whether this was an authority to proceed with the sinking of a new well, as it also asked what the cost of other work in connection with a new well would be. — I immediately asked Miss Blanchfield to write and wire the Department asking that someone from the Dominion Water and Power Bureau be put in charge of the well. A reply to this was received by wire on the 24th ultimo; Father Charron was informed at once, and work on the new well (drilling) was commenced on Monday, January 27th.

I asked Rev. Father Charron, Mr. A. McMillan, Clerk in Charge, and Mr. Maughan, the well driller, to come to Calgary on the 28th ultimo, which they did.

The 6 5/8" casing recommended by Mr. Maughan, which was to cost $1.50 per foot, could not be procured; (this size is not now manufactured). I therefore ordered full 6" lined pipe, at a cost of $1.88 per foot; also a new shoe — $20.00; and extra collars at $1.75 each. These were sent out immediately.

We also discussed and obtained prices on a new electric motor to operate the pump; also the excavating, &c., of a pit to house same. These matters were reported to the Department by Mr. McMillan, at my request.

Mr. P.A. Fetterly of the Dominion Water and Power Bureau was with us on the 28th ultimo, and gave us some pointers on certain matters. I had tried to contact him several times: before; twice before going to the Blood Reserve on the 9th of January, and again after my return; but was unsuccessful, as he was out of the city.

As regards the pupils having been sent back to their homes: This was done before I was informed that the water supply at the school had failed; and I think it was the proper thing.

R. A. Hoey, Esq.,

Sir:-

Blood R.C. School Well

I beg to advise further to my letter of the 7th inst., the following is a complete report to date of the work done on this well.

After striking a good flow of water at the depth of 206', and testing the flow for 6 hours after which the pump rods broke, after they had been fixed and pumping started over again, it was found that a large quantity of sand was passing through the pump and increasing all the time. The sand turned out to be quick sand and although the sample had been sent to Cooke Boren Co Indians to have a screen made it was felt that unless the large flow of sand could be controlled the screen when installed would gradually fill up and clog the screen.

While awaiting the delivery of the screen numerous tests were made to see if the well had cleared of the sand and on February 14th after consultation with Father Charron we decided to drill the well deeper to try and locate water in the Limestone; this was done and the well was lowered to 245 feet, and we have now a fine flow of water without showing of sand. The well screen has arrived in Lethbridge and will be installed tomorrow, if the well shows no sign of sand, and the flow after the test is satisfactory, every effort will be made to have the pit dug and the pump room fixed up, pipe connections made and the motor installed, with as little delay as possible.

I understand Father Charron intends to reopen School as soon as possible, and as connections are being temporary made to the Tower he hopes to have the children back in school at the end of this week.

In authorizing the deepening of the well I did this for the benefit of trying to fulfill the Department's request to expedite the finding of water for this School, and trust you will concur in the extra drilling authorized.

A further report along with the vouchers will be forwarded on completion of this well.

Sir:

Blood R C School New Well.

I beg to make the following report on the new well at the R C School. The drilling has been completed, gravel screen and pump have been installed, and the concreteing of the pit started and will be finished by March 7th, when the plumbing and motors will be installed. I am forwarding with this letter vouchers to cover drilling and expenses incurred in placing screen in the bottom of well, as follows.

**Drilling Installing Pump & Screen**

Total depth of the well is 245 feet at $1.50 per foot amounting to $367.50. Well Test of 24 Hours at $1.50 made at the 205 foot mark $30.00. This test proving that the water was coming through quick sand, and was filling the well with sand, this caused the deepening of the well to 245 feet where water was located in sand stone. At the 245 foot mark a test of 12 Hours was made at $1.50 per foot making $18.00. This was followed by the installation of the gravel screen after which the test was renewed for another 12 Hours at $1.50 costing $18.00. The installation of the screen cost $40.00 this account having been arranged for with the well driller while discussing the new well in Calgary. The 25 feet of casing supplied by Mr. Maughan was 5" inside diameter to assist in putting in the screen, and replaces the piping charged by Wilkinson & Mclean from whom we received a credit note, and was threaded to suit gravel screen. The small items charged on this account took care of the necessary repairs needed to put casing in shape, and welding and pipe hook to lower screen into well, machining and threading plug to fit connections from wooden rod to cylinder these items paid by Mr. Maughan total $7.25 for which receipts are attached, making the total of $322.50. The well driller during tests lowered the pump four times and pulled it three times without charge. The working barrel shipped from Indiana will be reported on when plumbing connections are made and Mr. Flett's account is sent forward.

**Gravel Screen**

This screen was ordered from A D Cooke Lawrenceburg Indiana, was shipped C.O.D. to Mr. Maughan and the accounts enclosed with voucher will show the different items to make the total value of the screen as purchased in the U.S.A., as $108.45. These are made up as follows:
- C.P. Express $2.59
- Value of screen $92.15
- Premium on Canadian funds $10.14
- C.O.D. Charges 17 cents making a total of $108.45. The entry for Home Consumption sheet shows Duty $26.00, Tar Exchange tax $10.50, Sales Tax $10.48 and charge of broker to handle release $1.50 Total $48.50 making a total cost of $153.95. This is payable to Mr. J P Maughan without commission on his part. A sketch of the installation of the Screen is attached it being put in, in 4 and 6 foot lengths.
Casing

This Voucher made out to Wilkinson & McLean covers:
1 only shoe $25.00, 241 feet of 6" Standard pipe at $1.8193 per foot amounting to $438.75, 4 extra 6" Black recessed couplings at $7.58 each amounting to $30.32. The balance of account is Cartage from Calgary covered by receipt from Freightways amounting to $15.60 or a total cost of $504.67 less a credit note of $31.84 for 17½ feet at $1.8193 returned, making Wilkinson and McLean account $472.83.

The excavation of the pit is completed and concrete is being poured, as soon as this is completed, the plumbing connections will be made and the motors installed. A further report will go forward to cover the completion of this work along with the Vouchers covering the accounts.

For the information of the Department I wish to advise that on the completion of drilling of the new well, Father Charbon in conjunction with his Church Authorities asked Mr. Laughlin to place a 4" casing in the old well and try and drill deeper, this was done and the well carried to a depth of 215 feet, where they introduced a 3" casing inside diameter and went down to a dept of 245 feet, where they got supply of water, this cost the School Authorities around $700.00, but giving a very small hole to get the water through, however this will always give this School a surplus well to fall back on if the new well at any time had to be shut down. This is for the Departments information only, no expense being incurred against us.

Sir:

I beg to make the following report in regard to the Drilling of Well at the Blood R.C. school, this report will cover the outstanding accounts and will complete this file. I am forwarding with this report Vouchers covering the excavation of the new pump house and the work in completing the Pump Room, the work in connection with the plumbing and supplying of working barrel and the installation of the Motors.

Construction of Pump House.

The voucher covering this work with Tender attached, is made out on the basis of making the Pump room 12' X 12', instead of 18' X 9', the difference being covered by an extra charge of $10.00 as shown in the original estimate. Total $310.00

Connecting Pipes and Water Barrel.

This Voucher covers the installing of Pump on new base, and the connections changed to the tower, the installation of all valves and check valves, and laying of drain pipe to run any overflow into trap. The Working Barrel Cylinder for this well is the only item in the whole estimate which has run over. This was caused by the following, Mr Flett on being asked for an estimate quoted $85.00 the price quoted him by an Edmonton firm, who intended to purchase in eastern Canada. Owing to the inability to get same this was ordered from Indiana U.S.A. and as this party had no Brass Barrels or any Barrel 36" they supplied a brass lined Working Barrel 48" and this Barrel on its arrival in Cardston cost $100.00. This Changes Mr Fletts account from $185.00 to $285.00, this is the only change from the original estimates to be made. Total Account $285.00

Motor Attachment and Motor.

This Voucher covers the installation of the Motors, supplying pulleys and installation, and is now finished. Total Cost $232.84.

This concludes the expenses in connection with the above well, and I might say that a very nice job has been made of the work done, and I am informed by Father Charron that he is very well satisfied with the work as done. The well is now giving a very strong flow of water, and I am satisfied is going to give this School excellent service for a long time to come.

Extract from Inspector Schmidt's report on the Blood R.C. Indian Residential School dated February 10, 1942.

MAIN BUILDING

As usual, I found this very clean and tidy. The dormitories are spotless and well aired.

The coping -- cement blocks -- on top of the brick walls, is becoming loose. The filling between the blocks is crumbling, and allows the rain and snow to penetrate. This water runs down the walls, and affects the inside plaster, which is becoming stained, and in some places loosening from the lath. There is now a danger of considerable damage being done to the inside walls, more so to the upper part (corners). I was told that some seven or eight years ago these joints were filled with Tremco; if so, this does not appear to be the remedy for the trouble. It might be necessary to remove all the coping blocks, build forms, and run fresh concrete to make a solid piece all around the top of the walls; or perhaps the present coping blocks could be covered over with some sort of asphalt mixture or compound, which would make it air- and water-tight. I am asking the Principal to call on the District Resident Architect at Calgary and discuss the matter with him on his next visit to the City.

The cement floor in the boys' playroom is again cracking: The crack runs at an angle from the S.E. corner of the room, across to the centre of the outside (North) wall. I am told this cracked some years ago, when it was patched with cement. It is now cracking again, and the concrete is chipping and crumbling for several inches on each side of the crack. There is something peculiar about this crack, which angles across the room, and which appears to have heaved a bit. It might be that there is a soft, wet spot, or a vein of water passing at this particular place. The floor needs to be repaired immediately, as there is danger of the boys tripping in this crack.
while playing. I have asked that this matter be attended to without delay.

EQUIPMENT

This is sufficient for all present needs. The top of the large kitchen range is badly warped, and that part immediately over the fire box is badly burned. I suggested to the Principal and the Agent, that they make enquiries at the closest foundry -- Lethbridge or Calgary -- re having a new top made; or write to the manufacturers and make enquiries. I stated that I would mention this in my report.
Ottawa,
March 5, 1942.

Sir:

I beg to request further to my letter of March 15th, 1942, File No. 402-11RC-A, that I may be advised regarding completion of the Coping around the Blood Indian R.C. Residential School.

To date we have spent $231.54 in the erection of a Hoist & Scaffold, with the balance going to the Coping as far as the monies were available.

The Coping on the South wing is now completed and the Hoist & Scaffold is still in place awaiting authority to proceed with and complete this work.

In your letter, File No. 103-2-5 of March 24th, 1942, you advised that nothing further for a month or six weeks and as it is now June and very heavy rains have fallen, and with the prospect of a rainy season to come, possible damage to the Building will be caused through leaks in the Coping.

The Hoist which has been left in place - to save future expense - is in the position of being dangerous if our usual high winds come during the Summer months, slight damage has already been caused to windows by the Hoist during one high wind-storm.

May I have the Department's instructions regarding the completion of this work, at present with the sum of $231.54 paid out to Mr. Weston on a Contract of $800.00, it will be necessary to have $568.46 to complete this contract.

T.R.L. MacInnes, Esq.,

Dear Mr Doucet:

The new academic year is just about to begin and I would be very anxious to know if you can see your way clear to give me help to make the church basement fireproof. As you well remember we visited the church basement and found that it would be an ideal location for manual training, providing the present wood ceiling is made fireproof. Moreover the old shop is too small & unsuitable for that work, something must be done. If the government is willing to pay for the material I would be anxious to go ahead with the work. All I need is about 3,200 ft. of "gyprock" and I will do this work with the boys. Would you be so kind as to look into this, knowing that I am only too willing to go ahead if I get this help. If you remember, we thought that $300.00 would do the job.

TENDER ON SUPPLYING AND INSTALLATION OF RESERVE HOT WATER TANKER AT THE ST MARY'S R.C. RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL, BLOOD RESERVE CARDSTON.

Re Hot Water Storage Tank for the St Mary's R.C. School we can furnish this tank size 12 feet by three feet six shell to be 5/16" plate with heating coil installed, and all necessary connections as shown on sketch, for the sum of Three Hundred and eighty nine dollars, $389.00 F.O.B. School.

For taking out the old tank, and installing the new tank we quote one Hundred and Thirty five dollars, $135.00.

F.W.Flett
I beg to advise further to the remarks I made in my report under the Reading of Schools in the January Monthly report regarding the temporary repairs at the Hot Water Tank at the St Mary's R C School.

I have visited this School at the end of February and found that the Tank was again leaking from corrosion, with a large number of places showing corrosion. I interviewed Mr Flett The Plumber, and requested him to give me a tender in four copies of the cost of a new tank and the installation of same.

In my opinion it would be very foolish to keep welding this tank, as it is very expensive to have a welding machine come out this distance, and it would seem that the tank is ready to leak at more than half a dozen places.

I am enclosing Mr Fletts tender along with a sketch of the Tank, and would advise that installation charges which may seem high, include the removal through a treble window removing concrete Million for the taking out of the old tank and the taking in the new.

May I be advised if the Department are prepared to authorize this.

Anthony M. McCaig

I beg to advise that Mr Ralph Weston, contractor, who has been working at St Mary's Church, reported to me that two of the legs holding the water tower at the R.C. School on the North side of the tower were bulging badly, and that the weight of the tower on the North side was being carried by the remaining two legs.

I beg to advise that I had to authorize the emergent clearance of the Cess pool at the R C School. This was placed in the hands of Ralph Weston who made a temporary exit to save the backing up of the sewer into the Baths and Toilets of the School.

He is now cleaning out the Cesspool which from the information he has now given me shows that this blockage has been slowly blocking up for the past ten years, and all pipes and bells in the cesspool are corroded and covered with a heavy layer of dark soil formed by the bacteria. The cesspool which is 75 yards from the School Buildings had backed up so that the sewage leaving the toilets would come back through the bath tubs, and vice versa, with the children just returned from their holidays this was a very dangerous state for the sewage system to be in, and I called on Mr Weston to make the necessary clean out of the system.

I called there today again before writing this letter, and am advised that Mr Weston has sunk a shaft behind the main cesspool so that at any time in future the cesspool which runs 12 feet under ground can be relieved without unnecessary cost. The sum of $225.00 has been named as the cost of the complete clearance of the sewage system. As this is a very miserable work I feel that the amount of cost is quite feasible.

I trust that you will concur in the action I have taken.

Indian Agent.

Indian Affairs Branch Dept of Mines & Resources Ottawa.

I beg to advise that on my last visit to St Mary's R C School, it was found that the fire Box in the Bake oven at this School was burnt out, and was in need of emergency repairs; Mr Flett the local plumber checked the Bake oven and the following will be necessary to put the bake oven in shape.

The installation of a complete new Fire Box, or Furnace Box as the Manufacturing Co call it, the replacement of a number of Bricks under the Bake oven, and the installation of four T iron Braces under the lower Oven. Mr Flette has written to the Firm in the East by Airmail for a price and information as to the possibility of immediate delivery, and on receipt of same will be able to give me a quotation on the repairing of the fire box.

This Bake Oven was purchased by the Department through Mr Flett of Cardston, see Department letter October 16th 1936, File 103-2-12. No repairs has been made to this Bake Oven since;

The Bake Oven is a No 4 Brantford Bake Oven with a capacity of 144 Loaves, and is made by the Brantford Oven & Rack Co Ltd, Brantford (1402) Canada.

This Bake oven is now being used as little as possible but when in full use handles approximately 175 Loaves daily and I feel that as this is an emergency repair, may I be advised by return Air Mail instructions re the repairing of this Fire Box; If advised with Authority to make the repair I will Night Letter Mr Fletts quotation as soon as I have received it so that no more damage may be done to the Oven as it at present.

REPORT ON BLOOD INDIAN AGENCY FOR THE MONTH OF OCTOBER, 1944.

Schools:
Both schools visited during the month, attendance had improved at the St. Paul's Anglican School, and at end of month visited 114 children in attendance, and the Principal still striving to gather in the remaining children. The children in this school appear bright, clean and have settled down. Manual training is receiving some attention there, and an instructor is hired every Saturday from the Cardston High School at a salary of $7.50 per day.

The attendance at the Blood R.C. School is very good, only one absentee at the end of the month.

QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING MARCH, 1945, ON BLOOD INDIAN AGENCY

General Administration:

Schools have been visited during the month, for report purposes and also with regard to repair work on heating and plumbing installations, painting etc.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.
I beg to state that an item covering the Flooring of the Dining Room at the Blood R.C. School, this agency, was included in Estimates 1945-46, Sheet #76691B, Page II, Repairs to Buildings, Education.

This item suggested replacing Concrete Floor in Main Dining Room with Hardwood Floor, at cost of Material $1,000.00 - Labour $650.00.

This Floor has been examined again this Spring, and it is in a very bad condition, has large cracks running in all directions, and slabs have sunk, leaving uneven surfaces with consequent cracks, and is considered unhealthy for a Dining Room, being subject to Dust and Dirt gathering in the cracks caused by settlement.

To the writer it would appear that the solution lies in one of two methods to re-condition this Floor.

1. Terrazzo covering: To do this it would be necessary to break down the present concrete and use this as a base filling, cover this with new cement mixture, and finish in Terrazzo finish.

2. Re-cover present floor of concrete, with Dry Kiln Spruce lumber, first cementing all cracks, and covering the lumber floor with Battleship Linoleum.

Details of cost have not been gone into, but the matter is submitted in order that the Department may instruct us in the matter of Funds allowable for this particular school.

J. H. Hugh,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

DIRECTOR,
SURVEYS and ENGINEERING BRANCH.

Re: Blood (R.C.) Indian Residential School.

The above-mentioned school is located approximately 6 miles from Cardston, Alberta. The Indian Agent reports that the concrete floor in the main dining-room is in very bad condition and has large cracks running in all directions. The slabs have sunk, leaving uneven surfaces, and the floor is considered unhealthy for a dining-room, being subject to dust and dirt gathering in the cracks. The Indian Agent considers that either one of the following methods should be used to recondition this floor:

1. Terrazzo covering - To do this it would be necessary to break down the present concrete and use this as a base filling, cover this with new cement mixture and finish in terrazzo finish.

2. Re-cover present floor of concrete, with Dry Kiln Spruce lumber, first cementing all cracks, and covering the lumber floor with Battleship linoleum.

It would be appreciated if you would have one of your officers visit this school and let us know the best way to handle the matter.

Acting Director.
QUARTERLY REPORT ENDING JUNE 30th, 1945, ON BLOOD INDIAN AGENCY

WELFARE AND TRAINING.

SCHOOLS. Both schools well attended during the quarter except for truants. The services of the RCMP used in some instances for the return of pupils who either ran away or did not return from week-end holidays.

The matter of the above truancy is now being dealt with on instructions from the Branch, and the contents of the Provincial School Inspector's Report being passed on to the respective Principals for their comments.

A number of pupils were hospitalized during the quarter at the Indian Hospital and returned to their respective schools on recovering.

Quarantine was placed on both schools during the month June due to an outbreak of measles, nine cases were reported from the St. Paul's Anglican School, none from the Blood R.C. School.

Premises at both schools are in fairly good shape, and improvements made at both schools without cost to the Department from appropriations. Painting of several buildings at The Blood R.C. School has been carried out, and are quite attractive, using white for walls and red for roofs.

The painting of the barns and house at the St. Paul's School has been completed, this was delayed due to bad weather.

The High Pressure Laundry Boiler was the subject of special letter seeking authority for repairs by the Lethbridge Laundry. Due to labour shortage, this work cannot be carried out till after the 9th of July, when this company will have a boiler man available.

The Motor at this school, used for pumping and laundry was sent into Lethbridge for repairs, and is now in use again. Further study of the plant at this school is being made, with a view to eliminating the costs of repair, and will be submitted to the Branch when compiled.

J.E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

Memorandum:

September 18, 1945.

Re: Blood Indian Residential School,
Cardston, Alberta.

With reference to your memorandum of the 8th instant, we have now received a letter from Mr. G.M. Walker with which he forwarded a report including data on subsoil conditions at the above, prepared by Assistant Engineer, N.E. Willett, of our Banff office.

This report deals exhaustively with tests made to ascertain the moisture content of the soil and the source and direction of water seepage below the basement floor.

An analysis of the report would indicate that the movement of ground water is from the north of the building where a natural water course, now filled in, is located, and over which a skating rink has been erected some 240 feet distant. Furthermore, the clay soil dries quickly and becomes extremely porous, allowing surface water to seep below the foundations and floors, where it finds no outlet, with consequent flooding of the basement and damage to the floor. It would seem, therefore, that water enters the building from the north and northeast, as test samples show the subsoil to the south to be dry and the natural drainage slope being southeast from the buildings.

Mr. Walker recommends that an 8" tile drain be laid 8 feet below grade along the north and part of the east side of the building for a distance of 305 feet, thence 332 feet at a falling gradient to an existing drain, and that no repair work be done to the basement floors for at least six months after completion of the drain, or until the subsoil has attained a sufficient moisture stability to warrant such repairs.

From a study of the data to hand, we concur in the above recommendation. The estimated cost of the foregoing drainage work, with supervision and incidentals, is $2000.00.

It is suggested that the matter be submitted to the Indian Affairs Branch for their consideration.

Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Memorandum:

August 22, 1945.

Re: Blood Indian Residential School
Cardston, Alberta.

As stated to you verbally by our Architect, Mr. Walker was requested to arrange for an inspection and report on the concrete floor slab of the main dining room at the above school, and in this connection we are now in receipt of an interim report prepared by Mr. Willett of our Banff office, in which he deals with this matter which may be briefly summarized as follows:

The concrete floor slabs of the entire basement have heaved, cracking the concrete and leaving an uneven surface. Furthermore, alkali water seeping through the cracks has caused the concrete to deteriorate and crumble along these openings. It is noted in the report that some years ago the concrete floor of a recreation room was removed and relaid on 1/2" of gravel. This floor has since heaved and cracked. It is felt that water infiltrates from some outside source into the building below the floor causing the clay sub-soil on which the slab is directly laid, to expand and contract alternately.

Mr. Walker advises that further investigation to determine the source of the water entering the building below the basement floor, is now in progress, and in his covering letter, advances the opinion that no new flooring would be effective or permanent until or unless the ingress of water into the sub-soil under the building has been stopped, either by drainage or by a removal of the source of the seepage flow.

Mr. Walker states that when the report on his complete investigation is forwarded, it will be accompanied by estimates of cost for such work as is deemed essential for the restoration of the basement floors.

In view of these facts, it is considered advisable to await a full report on the cause and source of water infiltration, before a study of assembled data be made and proposals to remedy the trouble are prepared.

T. S. Mills
Chief Engineer.

Re: Blood (R.C.) Indian Residential School,
Cardston, Alberta.

In connection with the memorandum dated November 28th last, bearing your notation of December 1st, and the attached letter of November 30th from the Principal of the above school, comment is furnished as follows:

The Principal's letter indicates his opinion, that by placing 18 inches of broken stone over the clay sub-soil of the basement, before a new slab is laid, heaving of the basement floors could have been prevented without undertaking the sub-soil drainage system now under construction.

Mr. Willett of our Banff office, who carried out the inspection, stated that numerous soil moisture tests showed conclusively that moisture penetrating the sub-soil beneath the basement floor was forming a clay of gumbo consistency, unstable as a bearing soil. The resulting volume changes and swelling pressures due to the addition of moisture to the clay has caused a general heaving of the floor slabs.

It is to prevent the addition of water to this clay sub-soil, and to stabilize the moisture content that the exterior drainage line is being constructed. Once the sub-soil is stabilized as to moisture content, by the new drainage line, a new reinforced concrete slab laid on 6 inches of broken stone should be a permanent solution of the problem. To cover the entire area below the slab with an 18 inch fill of broken stone would, no doubt, temporarily alleviate the condition of heaving but would not permanently remedy the situation.

We trust that this presentation of our analysis of the requirements will be satisfactory, both to Indian Affairs Branch and to the Principal.

T. S. Mills,
Chief Engineer.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,

I beg to state that the Principal of the Blood R.C. School, this Reserve, has approached the writer with a view to obtaining a new Deep Well Ejector Pump, stating that the old Pump & Jack now in use, and which has been in operation since the building of the School in 1925, is obsolete and worn out.

I viewed the Pump & Jack, and found that the Gears driving this Jack were worn to the point that they slip gears with consequent slippage to the Pump, and is, as a result, not pumping the quantity of water required to meet all requirements.

The Principal has obtained from the Fairbanks-Morse Co. Ltd., CALGARY, Alta., prices in the type of installation he requires or believes satisfactory for this School, this letter being attached herewith, together with the data sheet on the suggested installation.

I have interviewed the Fairbanks-Morse representative and their Carleton Agent, J. Woslyng, Esq., and placed before them the requirements which are as follows:

- Depth of Well: 246 Feet.
- Distance Well to Tower: 150 Horizontal Feet
- Capacity of Tank: 40,000 Gallons.
- Depth of Pump Cylinder in well casing: 105 Feet.
- Size of Cylinder: 3 inches.
- Casting: 6 Do.
- Water Main to Tower: 2" Pipe - Discharged through same Pipe to Service.

Type of Pump requested:

Model #5007 D P.
Fairbanks-Morse Deep Well Double Pipe System Pump, with 5 HP Motor - 3 Phase - 60 Cycle - 220 Volts.
Price quoted: $856.70 - F.O.B. Calgary, Alta.

Freight approximately $12.00.
Installation by J. Woslyng: $25.00, this would cover setting Pump-Head and Ejector union on casing, making new bearing bolt holes, or leading same and making all electric connections to switches now in use and which would serve the new installation.

This subject matter is respectfully submitted for consideration and is worthy of such in view of the present equipment being worn and obsolete and in use for 20 years, and is recommended.

May we ask for the return to Rev. Father P.A. Charron of the letter and data sheet enclosed, please.

J. E. Hugh,
Indian Agent.

Enclos. /H.

I beg to state further to Branch letter #102-2-5 of the 26th September last, pertaining to the Basement Floor of the Blood R.C. Ind. Res. School, that the Principal has called my attention to the condition of the sub-cellar under the Basement of this School on the North side of the building, used for storage of Perishables, and the necessity of an Electric Sump Pump being installed in this sub-cellar to draw off draining water.

The Principal informs me that this was called to the attention of the Engineer-in-charge of the draining work carried out last fall at this School, and the latter is aware of the fact that the drain put in, is slightly higher than the sub-cellar floor, and consequently, the drainage ditch did not draw off the seepage from the Spring thaws, but, the Principal advises, rather added to the seepage.

Under these circumstances it is suggested that when the Basement Floors are being re-made this Summer, that an amount be allowed to re-floor this sub-cellar, providing "Weeping Tile" under the floor into a "Sump Hole", and installing an Electric Sump Pump to lift the water from the "Sump" to the drainage system of the School.

May this suggestion be considered when the Surveys & Engineering Branch are carry out the floor work.

J. E. Pugh,
Indian Agent.

As requested we herewith submit our Tender for to do the following Plumbing at the above School:-

Then we break the cement floor and make proper connections for to fit in individual Toilets in place of the Batterys above, making a total of 15 (Fifteen) W. C's.

MEMORANDUM:

Re: Proposed New Basement Floors,
Blood Indian Residential School,
Cardston, Alberta.

Further to our memorandum of May 16th last with respect to the renewal of basement floors at the above school, an inspection was carried out on June 7th last and a report prepared by Mr. W. H. Smolson of our Banff office, has been received. We have analyzed this report which may be summarized as follows:

The 8 inch tile drain installed to intercept ground water previously entering the building beneath the basement floors, has proved to be efficient, observation showing an appreciable flow of water being discharged from the outlet.

The purpose of the 8 inch drain to assist in the stabilization of the soil moisture content below the basement floors, has been largely achieved. The soil moisture content based on a series of tests made June 7th last, now shows a practically uniform condition to a depth of 6 feet.

The satisfactory functioning of the drain should prevent the inflow of further water into the sub-soil under the floors and as this sub-soil is a heavy clay, the moisture content from now on should change very little especially under the floors, and floors constructed as later specified herein, should be permanently satisfactory.

The areas with floors to which attention should be given are tabulated as follows:

In carrying out construction of new floors in the school, the following specification should be followed:

The existing floors should be entirely removed and soil excavated to a depth of 17 inches below the present floor level, and all surplus soil and debris removed from the building.

The new floor should be a 4 inch concrete slab of a mix consisting of one part Portland cement, two parts fine aggregate and three parts coarse aggregate not over ½ inches in size. Steel reinforcement should be 6 inch by 6 inch by ¼ inch wire mesh laid 1 inch below top of slab. A ½ inch finish consisting of one part Portland cement to two parts coarse sand mixed with a minimum of water, should be applied to the slab as soon as practicable after it has been laid.

Three lines of 4 inch tile drain should be laid lengthwise of the building to empty into the existing 8 inch drain outside of the building. These lines should be laid by tile scoop and embedded into the clay at the bottom of the floor excavation with the invert of the tile approximately 17 inches below grade. One line of tile should go longitudinally through the centre of the main building or in a south to north direction; one tile should be run parallel to the centre tile on each side of the building, and 5 feet from the wall footings. These three tile lines should be joined outside the building to enter the existing 8 inch tile drain through an 8 inch tee.

It is estimated that to carry out the above work, costs would be approximately as follows:

- Poor Floors ............. $5550 sq. ft. at $0.60 .... $3,330.00
- Fair Floors ............. 1519 sq. ft. at $0.60 .... $911.40

Mr. Snalson recommends that floors indicated as "Poor", should be laid during the school holiday season.

T.S. Mills
Chief Engineer.

No: Sub-cellar Drainage,
Blood Indian Residential School,
Cardston, Alberta.

With reference to your marginal notation dated May 20th last, on the memorandum of May 7th from the Director of Indian Affairs, we are now in receipt of a report prepared by Mr. Snellen of our Banff office.

The report states that, at present, water is siphoned from a circular hole approximately 8' in diameter and 3' deep, in the earthen floor of the sub-cellar by means of a small 1" wash tub drainer into a soil pipe connected with the sewer system of the building.

He recommends that the following installation be carried out:

(a) That two 8" x 30" sewer tiles be set vertically on a prepared gravel bottom and packed with gravel on the outside, giving a sump 8'-0" in diameter by 5'-0" high.

(b) That this sump be covered with a tight wooden cover on which would be installed a Canadian Fairbanks-Morse National Automatic Electric Sump Pump with 110 Volt, 60 Cycle, A.C. Motor.

(c) That the pump be installed to discharge into the soil pipe running across the ceiling of the sub-cellar through some 50 lineal feet of 1½" galvanized iron pipe with one 90 degree and one 45 degree - 1½" elbows.

(d) That this pump be connected to the electrical system of the building by 50 lineal feet of suitable rubber covered cable.

The estimated cost of the installation including all materials and labour, as well as supervision and contingencies, would be in the neighborhood of $100.00.

J. M. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
OTTAWA, Ontario.
We concur with Mr. Snolson's recommendation except that it is considered advisable to provide ½" galvanized iron conduit for the protection of the rubber covered cable from dampness. This installation could be carried out independently if materials are available or might be carried out in conjunction with new basement floor slab construction if the latter is approved.

T. S. Mills
Chief Engineer

Memorandum

Re: New Basement Floors
Blood Indian Residential School,
Cardston, Alberta.

With reference to your marginal note dated August 30th, on memorandum from the Director of Indian Affairs of August 28th, we have to comment as follows:

Constructing the dining room floor only will necessitate leaving out proposed four inch tile drains, which are an integral part of the original scheme for maintaining soil stability. These drains were proposed to underlay entire extent of main basement floor and connect to the eight inch tile drain previously constructed, among other considerations, for this purpose.

We feel reluctant to depart from the initial layout, which was given considerable study. To construct the dining room floor only would necessitate leaving out the sub-drainage to which we attach considerable importance.

We do not recommend that this work be undertaken alone, but should be considered a unit in the entire basement floor system when all the floors should be relaid at the same time in conjunction with the drains.

Chief Engineer,

J. H. Wardle, Esq.,
Director,
Surveys and Engineering Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

I wrote you in September, suggesting that part of the R.C.A.F. Training Center at Macleod, Alberta, would make an excellent residential school. You replied to that letter on the 23rd and stated that there was no authority in the Act at present for the operation of non-sectarian residential schools.

At that time there was little I could say in answer to that, because the buildings and their location were such that it did not appear to me to be good business to try to use them in any other location.

The schools on the Blood Reserve are some thirty miles to the south of this point and a river lies between them and the airport site. It would not be economical to tear them down and build them up again, and it would be impossible to move them over the river. Most of the buildings are too big to move with the type of equipment that is available.

Despite the fact that there is not yet any authority for a non-sectarian school, I approached a missionary of the R.C. church and asked what might be the objection of his church to the establishment of one. He stated that the pupils of the R.C. faith must get certain definite religious education, but that this could be given at a time that would not break into the usual school routine. Since there are many buildings to choose from in this center, accommodation could be easily supplied to the churches that desire local representatives.

As to staff, I believe I can find an excellent principal for such a school. If salaries were equal to that of provincial schools, there will be applicants as the type of school and location would have some attraction.

It is to be admitted that the whole does appear difficult under existing conditions and maybe the effort to establish a non-sectarian school is not warranted. I would, however, hate to see the idea dropped.

From another source, the suggestion was made that two residential schools be established here (a P. C. and an Anglican), to take all the children from the Peigan Reserve and the surplus children from the Blood Reserve. I think this is worth consideration.

The schools on the Peigan Reserve are anything but attractive and are not large enough. The
R. A. Hoey, Esq.

R. C. School has been trying to locate water for years and has not yet succeeded. Both schools are built on the bald-headed prairie where the wind is terrific, and the staff and pupils are not very happy. During a large part of the year it is difficult to get to them and the cost of transportation from railroad is considerable. Furthermore, the Anglicans have great difficulty in retaining staff.

The training center is of one storey construction and is situated right opposite the town of Macleod. It was originally erected for temporary use and the construction is more or less temporary. It is our surmise, however, that the buildings would remain in reasonably good condition for at least ten years and therefore more than sufficient in the center to meet all requirements for two complete institutions. Dear Mr. Hoey,

Reverend Fr. P. Charron, the principal of St. Mary's Indian Residential School on the Blood Reserve, has received a fairly large sum of money from the Oblates of Mary Immaculate missionary fund, which it is his purpose to use in the erection of a gymnasium for the use of his school children.

It has long been estimated that a building of this nature is quite essential for the education of the Indian children of that reserve. The broken up winter makes it quite impossible to have a skating rink and other winter sports enjoyed by nearly all our residential schools. For long weeks at a time, the children are forced to spend their recreation hours in recreation rooms considered too small for the purpose.

Moreover, the space allowed in the school for recreational purposes is so small that it is very difficult to train the children in sports and health activities. Discipline for both boys and girls becomes a serious problem and cannot be directed along character building lines.

Much emphasis is now being placed on the general health of the population of this reserve, and we consider that our school children are deprived of the necessary protection when forced to remain long periods in crowded and poorly ventilated recreation halls. This gymnasium and recreation centre will therefore fill a long needed want in this respect.

With a gymnasium most of these obstacles will disappear as such activities as basket-ball, indoor tennis and badminton will be a source of enjoyment beneficial to all the children of the school. It is also hoped that in time bowling alleys will be provided and that the young men and women of
the reserve will be attracted to take a keener interest in sports with subsequent beneficial results from both an educational and moral point of view. Moreover, the members of the Blood Reserve participate in sporting events the major part of which requires training in a gymnasium, and they all feel that they should have such a centre to enable them to meet and compete with children of other schools and localities.

If the principal is able to secure the recreational gymnasium of the R.C.A.F. establishment at McLeod, the construction of this recreation centre will become relatively easy. If not, he will use the ordinary building methods, and hopes to have the building completed a year from next September.

Hoping that you will give this project your sanction,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
Dear Father Plourde:

Your letter of January 20th addressed to Mr. Hoey has been referred to me.

This week I had the pleasure of a visit from Reverend Father Charron, Principal of the Blood School and I informed him regarding the action which the Department is taking with reference to securing a building which Father Charron desires. Negotiations in connection with the building are proceeding satisfactorily and I believe that Father Charron is satisfied with the action that we are taking.

Yours truly,

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Avenue East,
Ottawa.

WAR ASSETS CORPORATION

January 22nd, 1948

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

Re: Buildings #22, #23 and #38
MacLeod, Alta.,
Building #12, Pearce, Alta.

Dear Sir:

May we be advised as to whether your Department is still interested in above mentioned buildings.

On January 2nd, we wrote advising you of prices figured at 5% of original cost, but have had no reply.

As we have various requests for buildings in this area from municipal bodies and the general public, we would appreciate hearing if it is your intention to exercise your Department's priority.

Very truly yours,

WAR ASSETS CORPORATION,

for R. D. Fraser, For Director,
Lands and Buildings Department.
